title: What If? Alternate History Scenarios
full_description:
1. In groups, you will explore 'alternate history'. This means asking 'What if...?' about the past.

2. Discuss how the world today might be different if these events had happened differently:
• **What if** the Vikings had established permanent colonies in North America?
• **What if** the internet had never been invented?
• **What if** Norway had decided not to develop its oil industry?

3. Choose one scenario and brainstorm three major changes we would see in the world today.

4. Share your ideas with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent for practicing conditionals (second and third). The original example (Spanish Armada) is obscure for this audience. The new examples are more globally or locally relevant. You can encourage students to come up with their own 'What if...?' scenarios as well.

title: A Day in My Life
full_description:
1. Think about a typical weekday for you. What is your daily routine?

2. In pairs, describe your day to your partner from morning to night. Use time markers (e.g., 'First, I...', 'After that...', 'Before I go to sleep...').

3. Talk about:
• Waking up and getting ready
• Your journey to school
• Your time at school
• What you do after school (hobbies, work, friends, gaming, social media)
• Your evening routine

4. Find three things that are similar in your routines and three things that are different.

title: Holiday Chat: Traditions and Dream Trips
full_description:
1. In pairs, discuss these questions about holidays:
• What are the main school holidays in Norway (e.g., høstferie, vinterferie)? What do you usually do during them?
• Tell your partner about the best holiday or trip you have ever taken. Where did you go and what did you do?
• Tell your partner about the worst holiday or trip you have ever had. What went wrong?

2. In a small group, discuss your dream vacation. If you could go anywhere in the world for two weeks, where would you go and why?

title: Plan Your Perfect Holiday: A Role-Play
full_description:
1. In pairs, you are going to plan a one-week holiday together.

2. First, decide on your budget and what kind of holiday you want (e.g., relaxing on a beach, exploring a city, an adventure trip).

3. Next, discuss and agree on a destination. You can use your phones to look for ideas on travel websites.

4. Finally, make a list of at least three activities you want to do on your holiday.

5. Be prepared to tell the class about the holiday you planned.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original role-play involved a travel agent, which is less common now. This version is a collaborative planning task between friends, which is more realistic. Encourage students to use their phones for research to make the activity more authentic.

title: My Ultimate Dream Vacation Pitch
full_description:
1. In small groups, your task is to design the perfect dream vacation. There is no budget limit!

2. Discuss and decide on the following details:
• The destination (be specific!)
• The type of accommodation (e.g., luxury hotel, beach villa, cabin in the mountains)
• A list of amazing activities you will do
• The food you will eat
• Who you would invite to come with you

3. Prepare a short, exciting presentation to 'pitch' your dream vacation to the class, as if you were creating a travel vlog.

4. After all groups have presented, the class will vote for the most amazing dream vacation.

title: Holiday from Hell: Role-Playing a Complaint
full_description:
1. In pairs, you will role-play a conversation between a hotel manager and an unhappy tourist.

2. First, look at the list of problems the tourist experienced on their holiday. As a pair, choose 3-4 problems to focus on.
• Problems: The room was dirty, the WiFi didn't work, the food was cold, it was very noisy at night, the swimming pool was closed, the room didn't have the sea view from the website photos.

3. Role-play the conversation:
• Tourist: You are very annoyed. Complain to the manager about the problems. Explain what you want (e.g., a refund, a different room).
• Hotel Manager: Listen politely. Apologize for the problems. Offer a solution.

4. Swap roles and try the conversation again.

tags.teacher_instruction: The role of 'travel agent' has been updated to 'hotel manager' to be more modern. You can write the list of problems on the board for students to refer to.

title: Digital Travel Project: Plan an Adventure
full_description:
1. In pairs or individually, your project is to plan a detailed, two-week adventure holiday.

2. First, choose a destination anywhere in the world.

3. Next, use the internet to research and plan a full itinerary. You must include:
• Flights (which airline, approximate cost)
• Accommodation (where you will stay)
• A day-by-day plan of at least five specific adventure activities (e.g., hiking, surfing, zip-lining, exploring ancient ruins).

4. Present your adventure holiday plan to a small group in the next lesson. Explain your choices and try to convince them it's the best trip.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original task was very broad. This version focuses it on planning a specific 'adventure holiday', which is an engaging theme. Encourage students to be creative with their activities.

title: Find Your Match: A 'Likes and Dislikes' Mingle
full_description:
1. Your teacher will give you a category (e.g., Music, Movies, Games).

2. Your goal is to find someone else in the class who has the exact same 'favourite' as you in that category.

3. Mingle around the room and ask your classmates questions. For example:
• 'What's your favourite type of music?'
• 'Who is your favourite artist?'
• 'What's your favourite TV series right now?'

4. When you find someone with the same favourite, write down their name. Try to find a match for several different categories!

tags.teacher_instruction: Write these categories on the board to guide the mingling: Favourite Music Genre, Favourite Movie, Favourite TV Series, Favourite Video Game, Favourite Food, Favourite Social Media App.

title: Let's Meet Up: Scheduling Challenge
full_description:
1. In pairs, you and your partner want to meet up sometime next week.

2. Your teacher will give each of you a schedule with some appointments already booked.

3. Talk to your partner to find a day and time that you are both free. You must also agree on something to do.

4. Start the conversation like this:
• Student A: 'Hi! Are you free to do something next week?'
• Student B: 'Yes, that sounds good! When works for you?'

tags.teacher_instruction: You must prepare two different weekly schedules (Schedule A and Schedule B) on paper. Make sure they only have one or two common free slots. For example: Schedule A is free Tuesday evening and Saturday morning. Schedule B is free Wednesday afternoon and Saturday morning. The solution is Saturday morning.

title: First Impressions and Connections
full_description:
In small groups, discuss these topics about meeting people.

• What are 'first impressions'? Why are they important?
• Have you ever completely changed your first impression of someone after getting to know them?
• Tell the story of how you met one of your good friends.
• What qualities do you look for in a friend?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original prompt about meeting a 'partner' was too personal. This version focuses on friendship and first impressions. The topic can still be personal, so foster a respectful and comfortable atmosphere.

title: Get to Know You: Paired Interviews
full_description:
In pairs, take turns interviewing your partner to get to know them better. You can ask about any of these topics, or your own ideas.

• Family and home life
• Hobbies and interests
• Your vocational subject (e.g., 'What's the most interesting thing you do in your workshop?')
• Favourite music, movies, or video games
• A TV series you would recommend
• Part-time jobs
• Future plans or dreams

title: Giving Advice: A Role-Play
full_description:
1. In pairs, you will role-play a conversation between two friends. One has a problem, and the other gives advice.

2. Your teacher will give you a 'problem card'.

3. Role-play the conversation:
• Student A: Explain your problem to your friend.
• Student B: Listen carefully and give some helpful advice. Use phrases like 'Maybe you should...', 'Have you thought about...?', or 'If I were you, I would...'.

4. Discuss the advice. Does Student A think it's a good idea?

tags.teacher_instruction: Prepare some 'problem cards' with modern, relatable issues for teens. Examples: • 'I spend way too much time scrolling on TikTok and I can't focus on my homework.' • 'I'm stressed about an upcoming exam and I don't know how to study for it.' • 'I have to work at my part-time job this weekend, but my friends want me to go to a party.' • 'My parents don't understand that gaming is an important social activity for me.'

title: Personality Talk: Strengths and Friends
full_description:
1. In pairs, discuss your personalities.

2. First, think about your own strengths. Tell your partner three positive personality traits you have. For example: 'I think I am a good listener,' or 'I'm very creative.'

3. Next, think about a close friend. Describe their personality to your partner. What makes them a good friend?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original task asked what students would change about themselves, which can be negative. This version is reframed to be positive and strength-based. The topic is still personal, so it is marked as sensitive.

title: Event Planning: The Perfect Get-Together
full_description:
1. In small groups, tell each other about the best party or social event you have ever been to. What made it so good?

2. Now, your group will plan the 'perfect get-together' for your class. It doesn't have to be a traditional party!

3. Discuss and make decisions on:
• The theme (e.g., LAN party, movie marathon, barbecue, sports tournament)
• The location
• The food and drinks
• The music (you could even create a short Spotify playlist)
• The activities

4. Prepare a short presentation to share your plan with the class.

title: Creating a Social Profile: A Writing Task
full_description:
For this task, you will create a fictional profile for a social app designed to help people find friends with similar interests.

1. First, decide on a specific interest for your profile (e.g., a video game, a music genre, a sport, a specific fandom).

2. Write a short, interesting bio (about 50-75 words). Your bio should:
• Introduce yourself (using a fictional name).
• Mention your main interest.
• Describe what kind of friend or connection you are looking for.

3. In pairs, share your profiles and give each other feedback. Is the profile clear? Is it interesting?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original 'lonely hearts' project is inappropriate and dated. This version is reframed for finding friends with shared hobbies. It is critical to stress that students must use fictional names and not share real personal contact information. This is a writing and feedback task, not a real social exchange.

title: Sports and Activities: From Sofas to Summits
full_description:
In groups, discuss your relationship with sports and physical activities.

• What sports or activities do you enjoy watching? Do you have a favourite team or athlete?
• What sports or activities do you enjoy doing yourself? (This can include anything from football, to gym workouts, to hiking (`gå på tur`), to dance).
• Do you consider e-sports to be 'real' sports? Why or why not?
• Tell a story about a memorable experience you had related to sports, either as a spectator or a participant.

title: Focus on a Sport: Rules, Stars, and Culture
full_description:
1. In small groups, choose ONE sport or e-sport that everyone in the group knows something about (e.g., football, handball, ice hockey, Counter-Strike, skiing).

2. As a group, discuss the sport you chose. Talk about:
• The basic rules.
• Famous players or teams.
• Important competitions or tournaments.
• The culture around the sport (e.g., fan chants, rivalries, special equipment).

3. Prepare to tell the rest of the class three interesting facts about the sport your group discussed.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity was only about football. This version is thematically adaptable, allowing groups to choose a sport they are interested in, including e-sports, which makes it far more inclusive and engaging for a diverse class.

title: Invent-a-Sport Challenge
full_description:
In groups, you are going to invent a completely new sport!

1. Brainstorm ideas and make decisions about your new sport. You must decide:
• The name of the sport.
• The objective (how do you win?).
• The basic rules.
• The number of players.
• The equipment needed (you can invent new equipment!).

2. Prepare a short presentation to introduce your new sport to the class. Be creative and try to make it sound exciting.

3. After all presentations, the class will vote for the 'Most Creative New Sport'.

title: Live Commentary: Sports and E-Sports
full_description:
1. In pairs or small groups, you are going to become sports commentators.

2. Your teacher will show a short, silent video clip of an exciting moment from a sport or an e-sport.

3. As you watch the clip, your group must provide a live, energetic commentary. Describe what is happening, who the key players are, and what might happen next.

4. Be ready to perform your commentary live for the class!

tags.teacher_instruction: You will need to have a few short (30-60 second) video clips ready to show. Choose exciting moments from a variety of sports and e-sports (e.g., a winning goal in football, a final push in a ski race, a key play in a League of Legends match). Play the clips without sound.

title: Research Project: My Favourite Athlete or Team
full_description:
1. For this project, you will research a famous athlete, e-sports player, or team that you admire.

2. Use the internet to find information about them. You should find out about:
• Their background and history.
• Their biggest achievements and successes.
• A challenge or difficulty they have overcome.
• Why you find them inspiring.

3. Prepare a short presentation (2-3 minutes) to share your findings with the class.

title: Getting Around: Commutes and Transport Debates
full_description:
In groups, discuss transport and how we get around.

1. First, talk about your own daily commute:
• How do you get to school? (bus, train, car, bike, walk?)
• How long does it take?
• What are the pros and cons of your way of travelling?

2. Next, discuss these topics:
• At what age do you think people should be allowed to get a driver's license? Why?
• What are the advantages and disadvantages of electric scooters in cities?
• How could public transport be improved in your area?

title: Giving Directions: A Map Challenge
full_description:
1. Work in pairs, Student A and Student B. You will each get a different map of a town.

2. Student A: Your map has several places marked 'YOU ARE HERE' and some empty squares. Your task is to ask for directions to find the places listed at the bottom of your map (e.g., 'the cinema').

3. Student B: Your map has all the locations marked. Your task is to listen to Student A and give clear directions.

4. How to ask and give directions:
• Student A: 'Excuse me, how do I get to the cinema?'
• Student B: 'Go straight on. Take the first left. It's on your right, next to the bank.'

5. Student A, draw the locations on your map based on the directions. At the end, compare maps to see if you were successful!

tags.teacher_instruction: You must prepare two different maps (Map A and Map B). They should be photocopies. Map A is for the asker; it has a starting point ('YOU ARE HERE') and a list of destinations to find (e.g., library, post office, park). Map B is for the giver; it is the same map but with those destinations clearly marked. This is a classic and highly effective information-gap activity.

title: Describing Famous Places
full_description:
1. In your group, choose a famous historical place that you know well. It can be in Norway or another country.

2. Prepare a short description of the place. Think about:
• Where is it located? (e.g., "It is in...")
• Who built it? (e.g., "It was built by...")
• What was its original purpose? (e.g., "It was used for...")
• What did people do there? (e.g., "They used to...")

3. Take turns presenting your famous place to your group.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original text had expressions in parentheses, which have been integrated into the student instructions as examples. This is a good warm-up for descriptive language and past tenses. Encourage students to think of both Norwegian and international locations.

title: Country Profile Exchange
full_description:
1. In pairs, choose a country you know well (it could be Norway or another country you find interesting).

2. Prepare to tell your partner about it. You can talk about some of these topics:
• History and key events
• Important people (heroes or famous figures)
• Politics or religion
• Trade and industry

3. Use question words like 'Who?', 'What?', 'When?', 'Where?', 'Why?', and 'How?' to ask your partner for more details about their chosen country.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is ideal for a mixed-nationality class but can be adapted. For a class of mostly Norwegian students, encourage them to choose different countries they find interesting. The original list of topics was very academic (e.g., colonialism, imperialism). Guide students to choose topics they are comfortable with and can speak about.

title: Historical Debates: Turning Points in History
full_description:
Part 1: Discussing Historical Eras
1. In your group, discuss the positive and negative impacts of ONE of the following historical periods:
• The Viking Age
• The Industrial Revolution
• The Digital Age (the last 30 years)
2. Share your group's main points with the class.

Part 2: Ranking Historical Figures
1. As a group, you must agree on the top three most important or influential people in world history.
2. Be ready to explain your choices and why you ranked them in that order. There is no single correct answer!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of people was Eurocentric and dated. For Part 2, you can provide a curated list of diverse figures (e.g., Greta Thunberg, Nelson Mandela, Marie Curie) or let students brainstorm their own. The goal is discussion and justification. Be mindful that discussions about certain historical figures can be sensitive.

title: Research Projects: Historical Impact & Modern Wonders
full_description:
This activity has three project options. Your teacher will tell you which one to do.

Option 1: Historical Impact Report
1. Choose a major historical period (e.g., The Viking Age, The Industrial Revolution, The Space Race).
2. Use the internet to research and identify five positive and five negative outcomes from this period.
3. Prepare a short presentation to share your findings with the class.

Option 2: The Seven Wonders of the Modern World
1. In small groups, research one of the 'New7Wonders of the World' (e.g., The Great Wall of China, Machu Picchu, The Roman Colosseum).
2. Prepare to tell another group what you learned.
3. After sharing, discuss in your group: What other places or creations do you think should be considered 'wonders' of the modern world? Think about technology, architecture, or nature.

Option 3: Dream Destination Pitch
1. Think of a famous monument or place in the world you would like to visit.
2. Use the internet to find information about visiting this place (e.g., travel options, what to see, costs).
3. In the next lesson, join a group and try to convince your classmates that your dream destination is the best choice for a group trip.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity combines three separate project ideas from the original text. I have separated them into clear options. The original mentioned "press" (newspapers), which is outdated. For Option 2, you may want to provide students with the list of the New7Wonders of the World.

title: Holiday Chat: Past Trips and Future Plans
full_description:
1. Work in pairs. You are going to talk about holidays.

2. First, ask your partner about their last holiday. Use question words to get more information:
• Where did you go?
• Who did you go with?
• What did you do there?
• How long were you there?

3. Next, ask your partner about their next holiday plan or a dream holiday they would like to take.

4. Be prepared to share one interesting fact about your partner's holiday with the rest of the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic pair-work fluency activity. The original's list of questions has been integrated into the instructions for clarity. To make it more inclusive for students who may not travel, be sure to emphasize the 'dream holiday' part of the prompt.

title: Insider's Guide: Top 10 Local Attractions
full_description:
1. First, as a class, let's brainstorm some general advice you would give a tourist visiting Norway for the first time.

2. Now, work in small groups. Imagine a friend from another country is visiting your local area or a Norwegian city you know well (e.g., Oslo, Bergen, Trondheim).

3. Your task is to create a "Top 10 Insider's Guide" for your friend. Write a list of ten attractions or activities.

4. Try to include a mix of famous tourist spots and hidden gems that only locals know about.

tags.teacher_instruction: Framing the task as creating an "Insider's Guide" makes it more engaging. Adding the whole-class warm-up helps activate schema. Encourage groups to choose different cities if possible to get a variety of recommendations from across the class.

title: Geography Challenge: The A-Z Game
full_description:
Let's play a geography game!

1. The teacher will start with a country that begins with the letter 'A' (e.g., "Argentina").

2. The first student must name its capital city (e.g., "Buenos Aires").

3. That same student then names a country that begins with the letter 'B' (e.g., "Brazil").

4. The next student must name the capital of that country ("Brasília") and then name a country starting with 'C'.

5. We will continue through the alphabet. If you can't name a capital or a country, you are out of the game. The last student remaining is the winner!

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic filler or warm-up game. It can be challenging, so you might consider allowing students to work in pairs or use a digital map if the level is lower. For a local twist, you could adapt it to be "Norwegian Fylker (Counties) and their administrative centers".

title: Holiday Negotiation Role-Play
full_description:
This activity has two parts. Your teacher will choose one.

Part 1: The Family Holiday Debate
1. Work in groups of six. Each person will get a role in a family that is planning a holiday together. Everyone wants something different!
• Grandparent: Wants a relaxing holiday in Norway.
• Parent 1: Wants to visit museums and historical sites.
• Parent 2: Wants a sunny beach holiday.
• Teenager (16 yrs): Wants an adventure holiday like hiking or climbing.
• Child (10 yrs): Wants to go to a theme park.
• Cousin: Wants a sustainable/eco-friendly trip.
2. Role-play the discussion. Your goal is to agree on a holiday destination and plan that makes everyone (mostly) happy.

Part 2: Unusual Holiday - Pros and Cons
1. Your class will be divided into two teams: Team A (Advantages) and Team B (Disadvantages).
2. Your teacher will suggest an unusual holiday idea (e.g., a week-long digital detox retreat, a volunteer trip, a survival course in the forest).
3. Team A brainstorms all the positive reasons to go. Team B brainstorms all the negative reasons.
4. After brainstorming, pair up with someone from the other team. Your new goal is to discuss the holiday and decide together if you would go or not.

tags.teacher_instruction: I have modernized the family roles and updated the unusual holiday ideas to be more relevant. This is a great activity for practicing negotiation, agreement, and disagreement language. For Part 1, you can write the roles on slips of paper for students to draw.

title: Holiday Planning on a Budget
full_description:
1. In small groups, imagine you are planning a one-week holiday together.

2. Your teacher will give each group a different budget (e.g., a very low budget, a medium budget, or a very high budget).

3. Your task is to plan all the details of your holiday. You must decide on:
• Destination
• Transportation
• Accommodation
• Food and entertainment

4. You must stay within your budget! Keep track of your spending.

5. After planning, write a short social media post (like for Instagram or TikTok) from your imaginary holiday. Describe what you are doing.

6. Finally, pair up with a student from another group and compare your holiday plans and experiences.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a solid problem-solving activity. I've modernized the "write a postcard" task to "write a social media post." You should prepare some simple budget amounts in NOK before the class (e.g., 3,000 NOK per person vs. 30,000 NOK per person) and write them on the board or on slips of paper for each group.

title: Sharing Adventure Holiday Stories
full_description:
1. Work in groups of four. Each person in the group will choose a different adventure holiday from the list below. Imagine you have just returned from this trip.
• Kayaking through the Norwegian fjords
• Hiking to Trolltunga or Preikestolen
• Surfing at Lofoten
• Dog sledding in Tromsø

2. Take turns telling your group what you did and saw on your adventure. Use past tenses to describe your experience.

3. If you have been on a real adventure holiday, you can share your true story instead!

tags.teacher_instruction: I have localized the adventure holiday locations to be Norwegian and highly relevant for the students. This makes the context more immediate and relatable than the original's suggestions (Amazon, Sahara). This is excellent practice for past tense narrative storytelling.

title: Digital Travel Agent Project
full_description:
This activity has two project options that require some work outside of class.

Option 1: The Critical Customer
1. At home, find a website for a travel company (e.g., TUI, Apollo, Ving).
2. Find a holiday package that looks interesting to you.
3. In your next class, work in small groups. Share the holiday you found.
4. As a group, choose one of the holidays and write a list of at least five important questions you would ask before booking it (e.g., "Are all meals included?", "What is the cancellation policy?").

Option 2: Plan a Two-Week Trip
1. At home, choose a country you would like to visit.
2. Use the internet to research information for a two-week trip there. Find a map and some basic info on costs, sights, and transport.
3. In class, work in small groups. Present your chosen country. As a group, plan a possible itinerary and a budget for a two-week trip in one of the countries.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original contained three distinct ideas. I've focused on the two most robust ones and made them clearer. Mentioning specific travel agents relevant to the Norwegian market (TUI, Apollo, Ving) helps students. The original title included `(www)` which indicated internet use; this is now assumed.

title: Hobby Talk & Leisure Time Discussion
full_description:
Part 1: Hobby Mingle
1. Everyone stands up. Your teacher will ask several questions about hobbies and free time.
2. When your teacher asks a question (e.g., "What hobby would you like to try?"), find a partner and ask them the question.
3. Listen to their answer, then find a new partner and repeat.
4. Be ready to share something you learned about a classmate.

Example Questions:
• What do you do to relax in your free time?
• What hobby would you like to try in the future?
• How much time do you spend on your phone or watching series?
• What is a popular leisure activity in Norway?

Part 2: Group Discussion
1. In small groups, discuss one of the following questions:
• What is 'quality time'? How much of it do you get each week?
• What is the right balance between school/work, hobbies, and relaxing?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity was overly complicated. I have simplified this into a standard 'mingle' format, which is easier to manage. I also simplified the abstract discussion questions ('work ethic') to be more concrete and accessible for B1/B2 learners, and modernized the examples.

title: Find Someone Who... (Leisure Edition)
full_description:
1. In your group, your goal is to find out which person...
• ...watches the most series or movies.
• ...has the most interesting hobby.
• ...has had the most different hobbies in their life.
• ...has ever collected something (like stamps, cards, or figures).
• ...spends the most time outdoors.

2. Ask questions to everyone in your group to find the answers.

3. Be prepared to report your group's "winners" to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a simple information-gap survey. I've rephrased it as a "Find Someone Who..." style activity, which is a familiar ELT format. I added a more modern prompt ("watches the most series or movies") and a Norway-relevant one ("spends the most time outdoors"). This works well as a warm-up.

title: All About Music: Q&A and Discussion
full_description:
Part 1: Music Q&A
1. Work in small groups. Discuss your answers to the following questions:
• What kind of music do you listen to when you study or relax?
• What subjects are most song lyrics about?
• Describe a concert or festival you have been to.
• What was the first song you remember loving?
• What music streaming service do you use (e.g., Spotify, Apple Music)?
• Who is a famous musician or singer from Norway you admire?

Part 2: Music Genre Discussion
1. In your groups, look at this list of music genres:
• Pop
• Rock / Metal
• Hip Hop / Rap
• Electronic (Techno, House)
• Russemusikk
• Folk music
2. Discuss the types of people or situations you associate with each genre. There are no right or wrong answers!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity was long and disjointed. I've turned it into a direct group discussion with modernized and simplified questions (e.g., replacing 'audio equipment' with 'streaming service'). I also localized the genre list by adding 'Russemusikk' to make it more relevant.

title: Desert Island Choices
full_description:
Imagine you are stranded on a desert island for the next ten years!

1. First, think about your choices individually. You can bring:
• Five songs or podcasts
• Two books or series
• One luxury item (this cannot be a phone, computer, or anything that can be used to communicate)

2. In small groups, take turns sharing your choices.

3. Explain to your group why each item is so important to you. Why did you choose it?

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic ESL activity. I have modernized the prompts from 'records' to 'songs or podcasts' and 'books' to 'books or series' to reflect modern media consumption. The core of the activity, justification and personal connection, remains the same.

title: Share Your Skills
full_description:
1. On a piece of paper, write down your answers to these three prompts:
• Something you are good at (a skill or hobby)
• Something you are not good at
• A new skill you would like to learn

2. Swap papers with a partner.

3. Ask your partner questions to learn more about their three answers. Be curious!
Example questions: "How did you learn to do that?" or "Why would you like to learn that skill?"

tags.teacher_instruction: The core activity is great for community building. The original text included an optional extension to have students prepare a 'lecture' on their skill. You could offer this as a follow-up '5-minute expert' presentation project for interested students.

title: English in the Real World: Songs and Courses
full_description:
Your teacher will assign one of the following mini-projects.

Project 1: Share a Song
1. Choose an English-language song that you like.
2. For the next lesson, be ready to share it with a small group. You can play a short clip of it.
3. Prepare three questions about the song's lyrics or message to discuss with your group.

Project 2: Find a Course
1. Use the internet to research a course or class available in your local area that you would find interesting (e.g., a welding course, a digital marketing class, a first-aid certificate).
2. In the next lesson, report back to your group. Tell them:
• What the course is.
• When and where it takes place.
• Why it interests you and how it could be useful for your future.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity combines two good project ideas. For Project 2, framing it towards vocational interests ('welding course,' 'first-aid certificate') makes it highly relevant for these students, connecting English skills to their career paths.

title: Discussing Money and Global Economics
full_description:
In your groups, choose one or two of the following topics to discuss.

Topic 1: Everyday Finance
• Brainstorm some advantages and disadvantages for each of these:
• Credit cards
• Mobile payment apps (like Vipps)
• Having a pension plan
• Student loans

Topic 2: Global Economics
• Do you think rich countries have a responsibility to help poorer countries? Why or why not?
• The world's richest people have more wealth than many countries combined. Should anything be done about this? If so, what?

Topic 3: Life Without Money
• How would our society work if money did not exist? Brainstorm some ideas.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original questions were quite advanced. I've simplified them into themed discussion prompts. The topics are still complex and require careful moderation. It's important to frame this as an opinion-sharing task, not a test of economic knowledge. Emphasize that there are no right or wrong answers.

title: Role-Play: Dealing with Unpaid Bills
full_description:
Part 1: Brainstorm
1. In pairs, make a list of all the regular bills a person might have to pay each month (e.g., electricity, mobile phone, rent, streaming services).
2. Discuss which of these bills are easiest or hardest to reduce, and how you could do it.

Part 2: Role-Play
1. Imagine a person has not paid their electricity bill for six months. You will role-play the conversation between the customer and the company.
2. Decide who is Student A and Student B.
• Student A: You work for the debt collection agency ('inkassobyrå'). You are calling about an unpaid bill of 5000 NOK. You must explain the consequences (e.g., power could be shut off, extra fees). You are polite but firm; you are just doing your job.
• Student B: You are the customer. You have had some personal problems and have not been able to pay. Explain your situation and try to negotiate a payment plan.

3. After the role-play, discuss with your partner: What solution did you agree on?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original scenario with a 'bailiff' is culturally specific. I've adapted this to a more common Norwegian context: a call from a debt collection agency ('inkasso'). The roles are also less extreme to reduce potential sensitivity and allow for more student creativity. This is excellent for practicing negotiation and problem-solving language.

title: Brainstorming Business Ideas
full_description:
1. In small groups, brainstorm five creative (and legal!) ways to make money or start a small business. Think about skills you have or needs in your community.
*Examples: starting a podcast, creating custom gaming controllers, offering a local delivery service, upcycling old furniture.*

2. Swap your list of ideas with another group.

3. Review the other group's list. Discuss which idea you think is the strongest or most interesting. Give them some positive feedback.

4. Get your list back. As a group, choose your best idea and prepare a short 'pitch' to persuade an investor to give you money to start your business.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original framing of 'getting rich' and marking ideas as 'immoral' can lead to tricky discussions. I have re-focused the activity on creative and entrepreneurial thinking, which is very relevant for vocational students. The peer feedback step is also more constructive.

title: Invention Pitch: The Next Big Thing
full_description:
1. In pairs, invent a new product or service. It can be a serious solution to a real problem, or a funny and creative idea.

2. Write a short description to explain what your invention does and who it is for. For example: "Our invention is a smart backpack with a built-in solar charger, perfect for students and hikers."

3. Now, team up with another pair. One pair will be the 'inventors' and the other will be the 'investors' (like on the TV show *Løvens hule*).

4. The inventors have two minutes to 'pitch' their idea and persuade the investors to give them imaginary money to develop it.

5. After the pitch, swap roles so the other pair can present their invention.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a role-play activity focused on persuasive language. The original context of 'bank managers' has been updated to 'investors', referencing the Norwegian show *Løvens hule* (the equivalent of Dragon's Den/Shark Tank) to make it more current and relatable.

title: Sales Pitch Challenge: Sell Me This Trash
full_description:
1. In pairs, you will be given an everyday, 'useless' object.

2. Your challenge is to invent a new, creative use for this object and prepare a persuasive 1-minute sales pitch.

3. Think outside the box! For example: "This isn't just a single sock, it's a luxury dust-cover for your smartphone to protect it from scratches!"

4. Take turns presenting your amazing sales pitches to the class. The most convincing (or funniest) pitch wins!

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the list of 'useless' objects on the board for pairs to choose from. Example objects: a snowball, a single sock, a used teabag, a broken plate, a clock with no hands, a bucket with a hole. For extra fun, you could bring in some of these objects.

title: Money Talks: Discussing Proverbs
full_description:
1. In small groups, read the English proverbs about money below.

2. First, discuss what you think each one means.

3. Then, discuss whether you agree or disagree with the message of each proverb. Why?
• You can't buy love.
• Money is the root of all evil.
• Time is money.
• A fool and his money are soon parted.

4. Can you think of any similar sayings about money in Norwegian? Try to explain them to your group in English.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of proverbs was long and contained some obscure ones. This version uses four of the most common and accessible sayings. This activity encourages interpretation and cross-cultural comparison.

title: Just a Minute: The Fluency Game
full_description:
This is a speaking game called "Just a Minute."

1. One student will start by talking about a topic given by the teacher (e.g., 'social media').

2. The goal is to speak for one full minute without:
• hesitating for too long (e.g., more than 3 seconds).
• repeating words or ideas.
• going off-topic.

3. If any other student hears a mistake, they can challenge, explain the error, and then take over speaking on the same topic.

4. Whoever is speaking when the 60-second timer ends wins a point for their team.

tags.teacher_instruction: The rules can be strict, so you might relax them for B1 learners (e.g., only challenge for long hesitations). Prepare a list of modern, relevant topics. Good examples for VG1 students: gaming, part-time jobs, 'russ', streaming services, fast fashion, plans for the summer.

title: 20-Second Speeches
full_description:
1. Work in small groups.

2. Your teacher will provide a list of topics.

3. Take turns choosing a topic from the list.

4. Your challenge is to talk about that topic for 20 seconds without stopping. The goal is simply to keep speaking and practice your fluency.

5. After your 20 seconds are up, the next person in the group chooses a new topic.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a low-pressure fluency builder, great as a warm-up. You can write topics on the board or use the variation: each group writes 5-6 topics on small pieces of paper, then swaps papers with another group.

title: Finish the Sentence
full_description:
Let's practice speaking spontaneously!

1. The teacher will give a sentence starter.

2. The first student will complete the sentence and then continue talking about that topic for as long as they can (e.g., 20-30 seconds).

3. We will go around the class, with each student getting a new sentence starter.

Sentence Starters:
• I always feel good when...
• When I was younger, I used to...
• I wish I could learn how to...
• The best kind of holiday is...
• In the future, I hope...

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a simple, effective fluency warm-up. The original list of sentence starters has been shortened and modernized to be more engaging for students.

title: Improv Conversations
full_description:
1. In pairs, your task is to start and continue a surprising conversation.

2. Student A starts with an unexpected opening line from the list below.

3. Student B must accept the situation as true and respond naturally. Continue the conversation for at least 30-60 seconds.

4. After your conversation, swap roles and use a new opening line.

Example Openers:
• "I didn't know you had a pet snake!"
• "So, you've decided to become a professional gamer?"
• "Is that your new car parked outside? It's amazing!"
• "You never told me you won the lottery!"

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic improv game that encourages creativity and spontaneity. The original's example openers (knitting, tarantulas) have been modernized. The key is for the second student to always agree with the premise ('Yes, and...') to keep the conversation going.

title: Role-Play Speeches
full_description:
1. Work in small groups.

2. Each person chooses a role from the list below.

3. Take a few minutes to prepare a short (30-60 second) speech from the perspective of your chosen character.

4. Take turns performing your speeches for your group.

Roles:
• An athlete who has just won a gold medal.
• The 'best man' or 'maid of honour' giving a speech at a wedding.
• The CEO of a gaming company launching a new video game.
• A popular YouTuber thanking their subscribers for 1 million followers.
• A team captain motivating their players before a big game.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original version of this activity included potentially sensitive roles (e.g., dictator, mourner) and was marked with a sensitivity warning. This version has been revised with more neutral, modern, and positive roles, making it safe and appropriate for a VG1 classroom. The `sensitivity_warning` is now set to `false`.

title: Tic-Tac-Talk
full_description:
1. The class will split into two teams: Team X and Team O.

2. We will play Tic-Tac-Toe on a grid on the board. Each square has a different topic.

3. Teams take turns choosing a square they want to win.

4. To win the square and place your mark (X or O) there, one person from your team must talk about the topic in that square for 30 seconds without stopping.

5. The first team to get three of their marks in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) wins the game!

tags.teacher_instruction:
Draw a 3x3 grid on the board before class. The original topics were dated and UK-centric. Use this updated, student-relevant grid:
Top row: Gaming | Music | The Future
Middle row: Part-time jobs | Social Media | Travel
Bottom row: School | Friends | Food

title: Secret Agenda Conversation
full_description:
1. Work in groups of three.

2. Your teacher will secretly give each of you a different topic on a slip of paper. Do not show your topic to your group members!

3. Your goal is to have a normal, 3-minute conversation with your group. However, you must try to guide the conversation towards YOUR secret topic as naturally as possible.

4. Try to talk about your topic without making it obvious what it is.

5. After 3 minutes, the conversation stops. Take turns guessing what each person's secret topic was.

tags.teacher_instruction: This game is great for practicing conversational strategies like topic shifting and active listening. Prepare simple topics on slips of paper beforehand. Good topics: your favourite film, plans for the weekend, the importance of exercise, a video game you like, the best pizza topping.

title: News Media Discussion: Traditional vs. Digital
full_description:
In groups, discuss the following questions about news media:

• What are the biggest news stories in Norway or the world right now?

• How do most people your age get their news? (e.g., TV, VG.no, TikTok, NRK, Instagram, YouTube)

• What is the difference between a traditional newspaper like *Aftenposten* and an online tabloid like *VG*? Think about their headlines, photos, and types of stories.

• Do you trust news from influencers on social media? Why or why not?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity was focused on outdated UK/US newspapers. This version has been completely localized for Norwegian students, referencing well-known local media outlets (VG, Aftenposten, NRK) and modern digital platforms (TikTok, Instagram) to make the discussion relevant.

title: Media, Privacy, and Fake News
full_description:
1. First, as a class, let's name a few celebrities or influencers who are always in the media. What kind of stories are usually published about them?

2. Now, in small groups, discuss these questions:

• Should there be limits on what the media can report about a famous person's private life? Where should we draw the line?

• How can you tell if a news story you see online is real or 'fake news'? What are some warning signs?

• Why do some governments try to control the news and limit press freedom in their countries?

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been updated to focus on the modern, critical concepts of privacy and fake news. The language has been simplified (e.g., 'stifled the press' became 'control the news'). The topic of government control of the press can be sensitive, so it's important to facilitate a respectful discussion.

title: Classroom Survey: Modern Media Habits
full_description:
1. In small groups, create a list of ten questions about how your classmates get their news today. For example: 'Which social media app do you use most for news?' or 'Do you trust news from influencers?'

2. Pair up with a student from a different group. Ask each other your questions and take notes on the answers.

3. As a class, share your most interesting questions. Your teacher will write them on the board.

4. Choose one question from the board and survey everyone in the class. Tally the results.

5. Present your findings to the class. For example: 'Sixty per cent of us get our news from TikTok.'

tags.teacher_instruction: The original task mentioned brainstorming alternative uses for a newspaper. This part has been removed for relevance. You can add a modern equivalent as a fast-finisher task, e.g., 'Brainstorm five creative ways to use a smartphone besides communication.'

title: Create a Class News Site (Project)
full_description:
This is a large project where we will create our own class news website or digital magazine.

Part 1: Analysis
1. Your teacher will show you the same news story covered by two different sources (e.g., NRK vs. a tabloid website).
2. In groups, discuss the differences you see in the headlines, language, photos, and overall focus.

Part 2: Planning
1. As a class, let's brainstorm different sections for our news site. Examples could be: School News, Gaming Reviews, Local Events, Sports Reports, Interviews, or Opinion pieces.

Part 3: Creation
1. Choose a section to work on, either individually or in a small group.
2. Your task is to create one piece of content for your section (e.g., write an article, conduct an interview, record a short video report).
3. Over the next few weeks, we will combine all the content to 'launch' our class news site.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original project was to make a physical newspaper. This has been modernized to creating a digital news site, which can be done using simple tools like a shared Google Doc, a class blog, or a Canva template. The original pre-activity on analyzing ads can be used as an optional add-on.

title: Norwegian Politics Quiz
full_description:
Let's see what you know about the Norwegian political system. Work in small groups and try to answer these quiz questions.

1. What is the name of the Norwegian parliament?

2. Can you name three of the main political parties in Norway today?

3. Who is the current Prime Minister of Norway?

4. How often are there parliamentary elections in Norway?

5. What does 'MP' stand for in English? What is the Norwegian word for it?

6. In what year did Norwegian women get the right to vote?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity was a long list of UK/US political trivia. This has been fully localized to Norway. Answers for you: 1. Stortinget. 2. e.g., Arbeiderpartiet, Høyre, Fremskrittspartiet. 3. Jonas Gahr Støre (as of late 2024). 4. Every four years. 5. Member of Parliament; Stortingsrepresentant. 6. 1913. A good extension is to have groups create their own quiz questions about Norwegian society to test each other.

title: Borders and National Identity
full_description:
This topic can be complex and sensitive. Please be respectful of all opinions during the discussion.

1. In small groups, discuss the question: What makes a country a 'country'? Brainstorm a list of factors. (You can consider things like language, shared history, geography, government, or culture.)

2. Discuss the following questions in your group:
• Can you think of any groups of people who want to form their own independent country today? What are some of their reasons?
• What are the pros and cons of having national borders? What might the world be like without them?

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a sensitive topic that requires careful classroom management. The language has been simplified from the original (e.g., 'frontiers' to 'borders'). The questions are framed to be open-ended to encourage discussion rather than demanding specific political knowledge.

title: Formal Debate: Agree or Disagree?
full_description:
Today, we will hold a formal debate in class.

**Motion:** "Schools should ban the use of smartphones during the entire school day."

1. The class will be divided into two teams: FOR the motion (you agree) and AGAINST the motion (you disagree).
2. In your team, brainstorm strong arguments to support your position. Also, try to predict the other team's arguments so you can challenge them.
3. Each team will choose 2-3 speakers to present the arguments.
4. We will follow this debate structure:
• Team FOR presents their main arguments.
• Team AGAINST presents their main arguments.
• Rebuttal Round: Each team responds to the other's points.
• Closing Statements: Each team summarizes their case.
5. Finally, the class will vote to see which team was more persuasive.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original debate motion was abstract and potentially sensitive. It has been replaced with a concrete, highly relevant topic for students. This makes the activity safer and more engaging. The formal debate structure is excellent for practicing structured argumentation.

title: Yes, But... The Debate Game
full_description:
Let's play a fast-paced debate game!

1. The class will be divided into two teams: Team A and Team B.

2. The teacher will call out a topic (e.g., "social media").

3. Someone from Team A must quickly state one advantage of the topic. (e.g., "Social media helps you stay connected with friends.")

4. Immediately, someone from Team B must challenge it with a disadvantage, starting their sentence with "Yes, but...". (e.g., "Yes, but it can also be very addictive and bad for your mental health.")

5. For the next topic, the teams will swap roles (Team B starts with the advantage).

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great fluency game for practicing agreement and disagreement. Provide a list of modern, relevant topics. Good examples: artificial intelligence, online shopping, electric cars, video games, fast food, reality TV. The original list included some potentially sensitive topics ('being a man/woman') which have been removed.

title: The Problem Housemate Role-Play
full_description:
1. Work in small groups of 3-4. Imagine you all share a flat ('kollektiv').

2. Your teacher will secretly choose one person in each group to be the 'problem housemate'. This person's secret role is to politely disagree with every solution the group suggests.

3. The teacher will announce a problem in the house (e.g., "The kitchen is always messy").

4. The group must discuss the problem and try to agree on a solution. The problem housemate must find a reason to reject every idea.

5. After a few minutes, we'll see if any group managed to solve the problem!

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a fun role-playing activity for negotiation practice. The original list of problems was a bit grim (mice, spiders). This version uses more relatable problems for young people. Example problems: The Wi-Fi is always slow; The kitchen is always messy; The neighbours complain about noise from parties; Someone keeps using all the hot water.

title: Creating an Inclusive Workplace Policy
full_description:
This topic requires respectful and thoughtful discussion.

1. As a class, let's first discuss: What does an 'inclusive workplace' mean to you? What makes a company a good and fair place to work for everyone?

2. In small groups, imagine you are starting a new company. Your task is to create a simple 'Code of Conduct' to ensure fairness and respect for all employees.

3. Your Code of Conduct should include your company's policy on key issues, such as:
• Gender equality
• Support for employees with disabilities
• Respect for different cultures and backgrounds
• A zero-tolerance policy for bullying and harassment

4. Choose one person in your group to take notes. Be prepared to share your key policy points with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been reframed from the vague 'equal opportunities' to the concrete and practical task of creating an 'Inclusive Workplace Policy' or 'Code of Conduct.' This is highly relevant for vocational students preparing to enter the workforce and encourages them to think about professional ethics.

title: Political Policy Brainstorm
full_description:
1. First, as a class, let's brainstorm some key policy areas for a government (e.g., education, environment, healthcare, economy).

2. Now, work in groups of four. Your first task is to imagine you are creating a new political party. Agree on your party's main policies for the areas we brainstormed.

3. In your group, one of you will be a TV journalist. The other three are party representatives. The journalist's job is to prepare questions to ask the party about their policies.

4. Role-play a short TV interview where the journalist interviews the party representatives about their new policies.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been reframed to be more creative and less confrontational than the original 'Left and right' debate. Instead of forcing students into pre-defined political boxes, they create their own party. This encourages thinking about policy without the baggage of existing political labels.

title: Current Events Reporting Project
full_description:
This project requires some research before the next lesson.

Option 1: The 'On-the-Spot' Reporter
1. Choose a major political or social news story that is happening right now.
2. Do some research from reliable news sources (e.g., NRK, BBC, Reuters).
3. Prepare to present the story as a short (1-2 minute) news report to the class. You can even do this with a partner, acting as a news anchor and an 'on-the-spot' reporter.

Option 2: The Global Leader Tracker
1. Visit the official website or social media account of a world leader (e.g., the Prime Minister of Norway, the US President, the President of France).
2. Find out what this leader has been doing recently.
3. In the next class, share what you learned with a partner.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original task specified the White House website, which has been broadened to be more globally and locally relevant. The news report task is timeless, but framing it with modern broadcast roles makes it more engaging.

title: Understanding Relationships
full_description:
Part 1: Analyse the Message
1. In pairs, read the following text message and discuss the relationships between the people mentioned. Who is Pat? Who is John? Who is Lisa?

"John, I've just gone out to get some pizza for the kids' dinner. They should be back from the park with Lisa soon. Don't touch the kitchen wall - the paint's still wet. Your sister Jean sent you an email. Don't worry - I didn't read it! Oh, and if Chris calls, I'm not here tonight. Talk soon, Pat."

Part 2: What's the Story?
1. In pairs, choose one of the sentences below. Spend a few minutes discussing what events might have led to someone saying this.
• "I'm in love!"
• "We broke up."
• "I'll never speak to them again!"
• "I quit my job!"
2. Find another pair. Take turns saying your sentence, and have the other pair ask you questions to discover the backstory you created.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity used a listening script, which has been converted to a more practical text message format. The core task of inference and discussion remains. Note that discussions about relationships can be sensitive.

title: Discussing Life-Changing Events
full_description:
1. In groups, discuss how a person's life and relationships might change after these major life events.
• Winning the lottery
• Getting a big promotion at work
• Moving to a new city or country
• Having a baby
• Going 'viral' on social media

2. Think about both the positive and negative effects for each event.

3. If you feel comfortable, you can share a story about a life-changing event that happened to you or someone you know. (This is completely optional).

tags.teacher_instruction: The list of life events has been updated with a modern example ('going viral'). It is critical to tell students that sharing personal stories is completely optional and they should not feel pressured to disclose private information.

title: Friendship: Then and Now
full_description:
Part 1: Personal Reflection
1. In pairs, discuss these questions:
• Think about your best friend when you were in primary school ('barneskole'). What were they like?
• Now think about your best friend today. Is it the same person? How has your friendship changed?
• In your opinion, can men and women be best friends? Why or why not?

Part 2: Discussing Sayings
1. In your pair, discuss what these sayings about friendship mean. Do you agree with them?
• "A friend in need is a friend indeed."
• "Opposites attract."
2. Can you think of any similar sayings about friendship in Norwegian? Try to explain one to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of sayings was long; this version focuses on two of the most common and easily understood ones. The core of the activity is personal reflection and sharing opinions respectfully.

title: Modern Romance and Relationships
full_description:
This topic can be sensitive. Please be respectful of all opinions.

1. As a class, let's brainstorm some ideas: How has dating and starting a relationship changed in the last 20 years?

2. In small groups, discuss these questions:
• Do you believe in 'love at first sight'?
• In your opinion, what are the most important things for a successful long-term relationship?
• How are relationships shown in movies and TV series? Do you think it's realistic?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original prompt used 'Romeo and Juliet', which has been replaced with more open-ended and modern discussion starters. The focus is on contemporary views of relationships, which is more relevant for VG1 students.

title: Famous Couples Quiz
full_description:
Let's test your pop culture knowledge!

1. The teacher will call out the name of a person from a famous couple.

2. As a class, shout out the name of their famous partner!

3. If you can, add one fact about the couple.

(For students from different countries): In small groups, tell each other about a famous couple from your own country's culture or history.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of couples was extremely outdated. Use this modern list for the quiz: Zendaya (Tom Holland), Taylor Swift (Travis Kelce), Justin Bieber (Hailey Bieber), Barbie (Ken), Shrek (Fiona), A$AP Rocky (Rihanna).

title: Dating App Profile Challenge
full_description:
This is a creative writing and role-play activity.

Part 1: Create a Profile
1. In pairs, you will create a dating app profile for an imaginary person. It could be a funny character or a more realistic person.
2. Write a short bio (about 30-50 words) that describes the person's personality, hobbies, and what they are looking for.
*Example: "Energetic, 22. Love hiking, gaming, and bad horror movies. Looking for someone with a good sense of humour who doesn't take life too seriously."

Part 2: Find a Match!
1. Mingle with the rest of the class. Take turns reading the profile you created.
2. Your goal is to find another imaginary person who would be a good match for yours.
3. When you find a potential match, talk with your new partner and decide what a first date would be like for your two characters.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been completely modernized from an outdated 'lonely hearts' ad to a relevant dating app profile task. Emphasize that this is a fictional, creative exercise. The topic is sensitive and should be handled with care.

title: Modern Partnerships: Contracts & Commitments
full_description:
This topic requires respectful and thoughtful discussion.

Part 1: Discussion
1. In pairs, discuss your opinions on these topics:
• Is there a 'best age' to enter a serious, long-term relationship?
• What are the advantages and disadvantages of 'arranged marriages' compared to choosing your own partner?

Part 2: Create a 'Partnership Agreement'
1. Still in pairs, imagine two people are moving in together for the first time. To ensure good communication, they decide to write a friendly 'partnership agreement'.
2. Agree on the terms for your agreement. Consider these issues:
• How will we divide housework?
• How will we handle money and bills?
• How much time should we spend together vs. with our own friends?
• How will we make important decisions together?
3. Compare your agreement with another pair. What was similar? What was different?

tags.teacher_instruction: The topic has been broadened from 'marriage' to 'partnerships' to be more inclusive. The 'marriage contract' task has been reframed as a more modern and less formal 'partnership agreement' to focus on communication and negotiation skills. This is a sensitive topic.

title: Family Structures and Dynamics
full_description:
Part 1: Comparing Families
1. In pairs, compare your family when you were a child with your life now. You can use these questions to help you:
• How many people were in your household?
• Were your parents strict or relaxed?
• How often did you see your extended family (grandparents, cousins, etc.)?

Part 2: Group Discussion
1. In small groups, discuss these questions. Remember to be respectful of different family situations and opinions.
• How has family life in Norway changed in the last 50 years?
• What are some different approaches to parenting and discipline?
• What are some advantages and disadvantages of being a single parent?

tags.teacher_instruction: The sensitive question about 'smacking children' has been replaced with a more open-ended question about parenting approaches. It is important to create a safe atmosphere for this discussion, emphasizing that all families are different and valid.

title: The Most Significant Inventions in History
full_description:
1. In small groups, brainstorm a list of what you think are the top ten most significant discoveries or inventions in human history. Think big!
*Suggestions to get you started: the wheel, printing, electricity, the internet, the smartphone, vaccines.*

2. Discuss your choices and agree on a final 'Top 10' list for your group.

3. As a group, choose your #1 most important invention. Be prepared to explain your choice to the rest of the class.

title: Debate: Animal Rights in Sports & Entertainment

title: Creating an Inclusive Workplace Policy
full_description:

• Support for employees with disabilities
• Respect for different cultures and backgrounds
• A zero-tolerance policy for bullying and harassment

title: Current Events Reporting Project
full_description:
This project requires some research before the next lesson.

Option 1: The 'On-the-Spot' Reporter
1. Choose a major political or social news story that is happening right now.
2. Do some research from reliable news sources (e.g., NRK, BBC, Reuters).
3. Prepare to present the story as a short (1-2 minute) news report to the class. You can even do this with a partner, acting as a news anchor and an 'on-the-spot' reporter.

1. Visit the official website or social media account of a world leader (e.g., the Prime Minister of Norway, the US President, the President of France).
2. Find out what this leader has been doing recently.
3. In the next class, share what you learned with a partner.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original task specified the White House website, which has been broadened to be more globally and locally relevant. The news report task is timeless, but framing it with modern broadcast roles makes it more engaging.

title: Understanding Relationships

title: Discussing Life-Changing Events

• Getting a big promotion at work
• Moving to a new city or country
• Having a baby
• Going 'viral' on social media

title: Famous Couples Quiz

3. If you can, add one fact about the couple.

title: Dating App Profile Challenge
full_description:
This is a creative writing and role-play activity.

Part 1: Create a Profile
1. In pairs, you will create a dating app profile for an imaginary person. It could be a funny character or a more realistic person.
2. Write a short bio (about 30-50 words) that describes the person's personality, hobbies, and what they are looking for.
*Example: "Energetic, 22. Love hiking, gaming, and bad horror movies. Looking for someone with a good sense of humour who doesn't take life too seriously."

Part 2: Find a Match!
1. Mingle with the rest of the class. Take turns reading the profile you created.
2. Your goal is to find another imaginary person who would be a good match for yours.
3. When you find a potential match, talk with your new partner and decide what a first date would be like for your two characters.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been completely modernized from an outdated 'lonely hearts' ad to a relevant dating app profile task. Emphasize that this is a fictional, creative exercise. The topic is sensitive and should be handled with care.

title: Modern Partnerships: Contracts & Commitments
full_description:
This topic requires respectful and thoughtful discussion.

• What are the advantages and disadvantages of 'arranged marriages' compared to choosing your own partner?

• How will we divide housework?
• How will we handle money and bills?
• How much time should we spend together vs. with our own friends?
• How will we make important decisions together?
3. Compare your agreement with another pair. What was similar? What was different?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of couples was extremely outdated. Use this modern list for the quiz: Zendaya (Tom Holland), Taylor Swift (Travis Kelce), Justin Bieber (Hailey Bieber), Barbie (Ken), Shrek (Fiona), A$AP Rocky (Rihanna).

title: Dating App Profile Challenge
full_description:
This is a creative writing and role-play activity.

Part 1: Create a Profile
1. In pairs, you will create a dating app profile for an imaginary person. It could be a funny character or a more realistic person.
2. Write a short bio (about 30-50 words) that describes the person's personality, hobbies, and what they are looking for.
*Example: "Energetic, 22. Love hiking, gaming, and bad horror movies. Looking for someone with a good sense of humour who doesn't take life too seriously."

Part 2: Find a Match!
1. Mingle with the rest of the class. Take turns reading the profile you created.
2. Your goal is to find another imaginary person who would be a good match for yours.
3. When you find a potential match, talk with your new partner and decide what a first date would be like for your two characters.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been completely modernized from an outdated 'lonely hearts' ad to a relevant dating app profile task. Emphasize that this is a fictional, creative exercise. The topic is sensitive and should be handled with care.

title: Modern Partnerships: Contracts & Commitments
full_description:
This topic requires respectful and thoughtful discussion.

Part 1: Discussion
1. In pairs, discuss your opinions on these topics:
• Is there a 'best age' to enter a serious, long-term relationship?
• What are the advantages and disadvantages of 'arranged marriages' compared to choosing your own partner?

Part 2: Create a 'Partnership Agreement'
1. Still in pairs, imagine two people are moving in together for the first time. To ensure good communication, they decide to write a friendly 'partnership agreement'.
2. Agree on the terms for your agreement. Consider these issues:
• How will we divide housework?
• How will we handle money and bills?
• How much time should we spend together vs. with our own friends?
• How will we make important decisions together?
3. Compare your agreement with another pair. What was similar? What was different?

tags.teacher_instruction: The topic has been broadened from 'marriage' to 'partnerships' to be more inclusive. The 'marriage contract' task has been reframed as a more modern and less formal 'partnership agreement' to focus on communication and negotiation skills. This is a sensitive topic.

title: Family Structures and Dynamics
full_description:
Part 1: Comparing Families
1. In pairs, compare your family when you were a child with your life now. You can use these questions to help you:
• How many people were in your household?
• Were your parents strict or relaxed?
• How often did you see your extended family (grandparents, cousins, etc.)?

Part 2: Group Discussion
1. In small groups, discuss these questions. Remember to be respectful of different family situations and opinions.
• How has family life in Norway changed in the last 50 years?
• What are some different approaches to parenting and discipline?
• What are some advantages and disadvantages of being a single parent?

tags.teacher_instruction: The sensitive question about 'smacking children' has been replaced with a more open-ended question about parenting approaches. It is important to create a safe atmosphere for this discussion, emphasizing that all families are different and valid.

title: The Most Significant Inventions in History
full_description:
1. In small groups, brainstorm a list of what you think are the top ten most significant discoveries or inventions in human history. Think big!
*Suggestions to get you started: the wheel, printing, electricity, the internet, the smartphone, vaccines.*

2. Discuss your choices and agree on a final 'Top 10' list for your group.

3. As a group, choose your #1 most important invention. Be prepared to explain your choice to the rest of the class.

4. For a final thought: What would a single day be like if there was suddenly no electricity in the world?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of inventions has been updated with modern examples to help prompt students. This is a great activity for practicing negotiation, justification, and comparative/superlative language.

title: Sci-Fi Futures: Predictions vs. Reality
full_description:
1. Think about a science fiction movie or TV series you have seen. (Examples: *Black Mirror*, *The Hunger Games*, *The Matrix*, *Dune*).

2. If you know one, briefly tell your group about the kind of future society it shows.

3. In your small groups, discuss these questions:
• In what ways can technology help build a better society in the future?
• In what ways could technology also be a threat to society?
• Has any technology from old sci-fi stories already come true today?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original book examples were dated. This version uses well-known modern TV series and films that are more likely to be familiar to students. The core discussion questions about technology's impact remain highly relevant.

title: Skepticism and Belief: Discussing Fringe Ideas
full_description:
This topic is about why people believe different things. Please be respectful of everyone's opinions and experiences.

In groups, discuss your opinions about the following phenomena. The goal is not to decide if they are 'real' or 'fake', but to discuss why people might believe in them.

• Astrology and horoscopes
• Ghosts and life after death
• UFOs and aliens
• Online conspiracy theories
• Good luck charms or superstitions

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a sensitive topic. The title and framing have been changed from 'Alternative science' to focus on the psychology of belief, which is a more academic and less confrontational approach. It is crucial to set ground rules for a respectful discussion.

title: The Impact of Modern Technology
full_description:
In groups, choose one or two of the following topics to discuss.

Topic 1: Artificial Intelligence (AI)
• What are the biggest changes AI is bringing to society?
• Do you think AI is more of an opportunity or a threat? Why?

Topic 2: Life Without a Smartphone
• Imagine a world where smartphones suddenly stopped working. How would your daily life be different?
• Make a list of five inconveniences you would face.

Topic 3: Advantages and Disadvantages
• Discuss the pros and cons of these modern technologies:
  • Social Media
  • Electric Cars
  • Online Shopping

tags.teacher_instruction: The original questions about 'intelligent computers' have been updated to focus on current, relevant technologies like AI and smartphones. The activity is structured into clear topic choices for the groups.

title: Research Project: Pioneers in Science & Tech
full_description:
This is a research project that requires some work before the next lesson.

1. Choose one of the influential people from the list below.

2. Use the internet to research this person and their main contribution to science or technology.

3. In the next lesson, you will work with a partner. Take turns presenting what you learned about your chosen person.

Choose from:
• Marie Curie (physicist and chemist, radioactivity)
• Tim Berners-Lee (inventor of the World Wide Web)
• Mae Jemison (engineer, physician, and first African American woman in space)
• Katherine Johnson (NASA mathematician whose calculations were critical to US spaceflights)
• Alan Turing (father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence)

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of scientists was not very diverse. This updated list is more inclusive and contains figures from the computer age, making it more relevant to modern students.

title: Sports Top Ten Lists
full_description:
1. Work in small groups.

2. Your task is to discuss and create 'Top 5' or 'Top 10' lists for the following sports categories.

Categories:
• The greatest sportspeople of all time
• The most popular sports in Norway
• The most iconic moments in sports history
• The best sporting rivalries (e.g., teams or individuals)

3. Compare your final lists with another group. Did you have any of the same choices? Be ready to defend your group's number one pick!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original category 'sporting disasters' has been removed and replaced with more positive and engaging topics like 'iconic moments' and 'best rivalries'. This encourages fun debate rather than focusing on negative events.

title: Extreme Sports: Pitch a New Sport
full_description:
Part 1: Discussion
1. As a class, let's brainstorm a list of 'extreme sports'. Has anyone tried one?
(Examples: snowboarding, bungee jumping, downhill mountain biking, surfing, paragliding)

Part 2: Invent a New Sport
1. In groups, your main task is to invent a brand-new sport. It can be serious, funny, or completely crazy.
2. Decide on the rules, the equipment needed, and what a player has to do to win.
*Example: "Our sport is 'Urban Volcano Surfing'. You use a special heat-resistant board to slide down the side of skyscrapers..."

3. Prepare a short pitch to present your new sport to the class. Try to persuade us that your sport should be included in the next X Games or Olympic Games.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity focuses on the most creative part of the original task, 'invent a new sport'. The brainstorming warm-up activates students' schema, and the final pitch encourages persuasive speaking.

title: Guess the Sport: 20 Questions
full_description:
Part 1: The Guessing Game
1. Work in pairs.
2. One person thinks of a sport, but doesn't say it out loud.
3. Their partner has to guess the sport by asking up to 20 'yes/no' questions. (e.g., "Is it a team sport?", "Do you use a ball?", "Is it played indoors?")
4. After the sport is guessed (or 20 questions are used), swap roles.

Part 2: Explaining Norwegian Sports
1. For this part, think of a sport that is very popular in Norway (e.g., cross-country skiing, handball, biathlon).
2. In small groups, take turns explaining the basic rules and goal of the sport, as if you were explaining it to someone who has never seen it before.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic ELT game. The addition of Part 2 localizes the activity perfectly, giving students a chance to practice descriptive language and talk about their own culture, which is great for building confidence.

title: Debate: Animal Rights in Sports & Entertainment
full_description:
This topic requires a respectful and structured debate.

Motion for debate: "It is wrong to use animals for human sports and entertainment."

1. Work in two large teams: one team FOR the motion (arguing that it IS wrong) and one team AGAINST the motion (arguing that it is acceptable in some cases).

2. In your team, brainstorm arguments. Think about different examples like horse racing, zoos, circuses, dog shows, or even animals used in films.

3. Try to predict the arguments of the other team and prepare your counter-arguments.

4. Work with a partner from the opposing team. Take turns presenting your arguments to each other. See if you can persuade your partner to change their mind.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original topic 'Blood sports' was highly sensitive and graphic. This version has been reframed to be a broader, more academic debate on animal ethics in entertainment. This allows for a robust discussion while being more appropriate for the classroom. Careful moderation is key.

title: Research Project: My Favourite Athlete
full_description:
In this project, you will research an athlete you admire and prepare a short presentation for our next class.

1. Choose your favourite athlete. This can be anyone from any sport.
