2. Use the internet to find information about them. Try to answer these questions:
• What is their background? (Where are they from? How did they start?)
• What are their biggest achievements?
• What challenges have they faced in their career?
• Why do you find them inspiring?

3. Prepare a short (3-5 minute) presentation to share your findings with the class. You can create a few slides or just use notes.

tags.teacher_instruction: Encourage students to choose a diverse range of athletes, not just the most famous ones. For students who need more support, you could provide a list of suggested athletes or a presentation template.

title: Discussion: Our Media and Reading Habits
full_description:
Let's talk about how we consume media and stories in today's world.

1. First, discuss these questions with a partner:
• Is storytelling important in Norwegian culture? Why or why not?
• What kind of books, series, or movies do you enjoy in your free time?
• What is the best story (from a book, film, or game) you have ever experienced? Why did you like it so much?
• Do you prefer physical books, e-books, or audiobooks? Why?
• Do you follow any blogs, webtoons, or online comics?

2. On your own, make a quick list of all the things you read in a typical day. Think about everything, for example:
• Social media posts (TikTok, Instagram, Snapchat)
• News articles on websites or apps
• Text messages and emails
• School books or work instructions
• Subtitles on a show

3. Mingle with your classmates and compare your lists. Who reads the most? What is the most common type of reading in our class?

title: Group Story Planning: Choose Your Genre
full_description:
In your groups, you will plan the beginning of a story. First, your teacher will give your group a story genre.

1. Brainstorm ideas for your story based on the genre. Make notes on:
• The setting (Where and when does the story take place?)
• The main character (Who are they? What do they want?)
• The first scene (How does the story begin?)

2. After planning, decide as a group how the story should develop and how it could end.

3. Be ready to share your group's story idea with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before the activity, brainstorm different story genres with the class and write them on the board (e.g., romance, horror, sci-fi, comedy, fantasy, crime/whodunnit, dystopian). Then, assign one genre to each group.

title: Collaborative Story Writing: The Genre Challenge
full_description:
Let's write stories together in a chain!

1. In your group, one person will be the secretary and start writing the beginning of a story based on the genre your teacher gives you. Everyone should contribute ideas.

2. After a few minutes, you will pass your story to the next group.

3. Read the story you receive from the other group, and then continue writing it.

4. You will repeat this process a few times. When your original story comes back to you, read the full story and correct any mistakes you find.

5. Finally, one person from your group will read the finished story to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: First, brainstorm a list of story genres with the class. Allocate a different genre to each group. Manage the time for each writing segment (e.g., 5-7 minutes) and signal when it's time to pass the papers. This activity creates a fun and low-pressure writing environment.

title: Story Battle: Fortunately vs. Unfortunately
full_description:
Let's build a story with a twist!

1. Your teacher will give you a story starter.

2. Group A must continue the story with a sentence that starts with 'Fortunately...'.

3. Then, Group B must add a sentence that starts with 'Unfortunately...'.

4. You will take turns adding sentences, making the story go from good to bad and back again!

5. The last group will add a final sentence to end the story.

tags.teacher_instruction: Divide the class into two teams: 'Fortunately' and 'Unfortunately'. Provide a few story starters on the board, e.g., 'He stepped off the bus and saw her on the sidewalk...', 'My phone suddenly died in the middle of the forest...', 'We were a poor family until we found something valuable in our backyard...'. This can be done orally as a whole class or as a written activity in pairs where they write and fold the paper (exquisite corpse style).

title: Collaborative Story Building: Describe the Scene
full_description:
Let's build a story together, piece by piece.

1. In your group of four, you will get a story starter from your teacher.

2. Each person has a specific role:
• Student A: Describe the first character (e.g., the old lady).
• Student B: Describe the second character (e.g., the granddaughter).
• Student C: Describe the location (e.g., the cottage).
• Student D: Describe the surrounding area (e.g., the forest).

3. Your teacher will then give you the next line of the story.

4. As a group, discuss and agree on what happens next. Take turns adding one sentence each to finish the story.

5. Finally, pair up with a student from another group and tell each other your finished stories.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the story starter on the board, for example: 'There was an old lady living in a cottage in the forest with her granddaughter...'. After the initial descriptions, provide the next line to move the plot forward: 'One day, a young man knocked on the door...'. This structured approach helps students focus on descriptive language.

title: Vocabulary Story Challenge
full_description:
Let's use our new vocabulary to create a story!

1. In your group, brainstorm a list of 15-20 vocabulary words we have learned recently. Write them clearly on a piece of paper.

2. Swap your list of words with another group.

3. Your group must now create a story that uses all the words from the list you received.

4. Take turns adding one sentence each to the story, trying to include one of the vocabulary words naturally.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great review activity. You can encourage groups to be creative and funny. You might want to model a quick example with a few words on the board before they start.

title: Reverse Storytelling: From Questions to Plot
full_description:
In this activity, you will write a story based only on a list of questions.

1. First, in small groups, write a list of 10 comprehension questions for a story that does not exist yet. The questions should hint at a plot. For example: 'Why did the robot leave the city?' or 'Who was the message from?'

2. Swap your list of questions with another group.

3. Now, your group must write a short story that answers all the questions you received. Be creative!

tags.teacher_instruction: To start, show the class a few example questions on the board (e.g., 'Why did Henry hide the key? Were the diamonds still there? How did he get away?') and ask them to guess what the story might be about. This warms them up for the main task.

title: Folktale Circle: Sharing Cultural Stories
full_description:
Let's share famous stories from Norwegian culture or from your own background.

1. In your group, choose a famous folktale or fairy tale that everyone knows. It could be a Norwegian tale like one about Askeladden or trolls, or a classic story like 'Cinderella'.

2. Discuss the story to make sure everyone remembers the main plot points.

3. Prepare to tell the story to the class. Each person in your group should be responsible for telling one part of the story.

4. Take turns telling your part of the story to the class, one person after another, to narrate the whole tale.

tags.teacher_instruction: First, find out which stories students know to help form groups. If you have a diverse, multicultural class, you can create mixed groups where students share a folktale from their country of origin with their group members first, before one group presents to the class. This is a great way to build community.

title: The 50-Word Story Challenge
full_description:
Can you tell a famous story in exactly 50 words?

1. Your teacher will first read a 50-word summary of a famous story as an example.

2. In small groups, choose a well-known movie, book, or video game.

3. Write a summary of the plot in exactly 50 words. Every word counts!

4. Swap your 50-word story with another group. Read their story. Do you think they missed anything important? Can you improve it without adding more words?

tags.teacher_instruction: Start by dictating the provided 50-word summary of 'Romeo and Juliet' or a more modern example like 'Harry Potter': 'An orphan boy discovers he is a wizard. He goes to a magic school, makes new friends, and learns about his parents' past. He must fight the dark wizard who killed his parents and now wants to return to power, facing him in a final, dangerous confrontation.' Then, challenge the students.

title: Story From Pictures: A Collaborative Creation
full_description:
Let's create a story from random pictures!

1. In your group, you will draw four simple pictures on separate pieces of paper. Your teacher will tell you what to draw for each.

2. All the pictures from all the groups will be collected and shuffled.

3. Your group will then receive a new, random set of four pictures.

4. Your task is to create a single, coherent story that includes all four of the objects, places, or actions in your new pictures.

tags.teacher_instruction: Divide the class into groups. Assign one person in each group to draw the following (one per paper): 1) a living thing (an animal or person), 2) an everyday object, 3) a place, 4) an action (e.g., running, sleeping). Collect all the drawings, shuffle them, and redistribute one of each type to every group. This randomness sparks creativity.

title: Digital Folklore: Researching Urban Legends
full_description:
For this project, you will explore the world of modern myths, also known as urban legends.

1. Use the internet to research an 'urban legend'. This is a strange or scary story that many people believe is true, even with no proof. You can look for famous international legends or Norwegian ones (like 'rotta i pizzaen').

2. Choose one legend that you find interesting. Read about it and take some notes.

3. In our next lesson, be prepared to tell the story to your group and discuss whether you think it's believable or not.

tags.teacher_instruction: Students will need access to the internet for this homework task. You can guide them by suggesting search terms like 'famous urban legends' or 'Norwegian vandrehistorier'. In class, facilitate a discussion about why these stories spread and what they say about our culture.

title: Survival Scenario: Message in a Bottle
full_description:
Imagine you are the only survivor of a shipwreck on a deserted island.

1. In your group, first discuss what 10 items you would save from the sinking ship to help you survive. You must agree on the final list. Be ready to explain your choices.

2. Compare your list with another group. Did you choose the same things?

3. Now, imagine you find a bottle and can send one message to the outside world. Write the message. It should explain who you are, what happened, and what your life on the island is like.

4. One person from your group will read your message to the class. We will then vote on which castaway most deserves to be rescued!

tags.teacher_instruction: To introduce the topic, ask students about survival stories they know from movies or TV shows (e.g., 'Lost', 'The Martian', or reality shows like 'Alene'). The original activity also included a historical discussion which has been removed for focus, but you could add it as an extension for interested students.

title: Survival Challenge: Desert, Jungle, or Arctic?
full_description:
Imagine you are survivors of a plane crash. You are not injured, but you are lost.

1. In your group, your teacher will tell you which environment you have crashed in: the desert, the Amazon jungle, or the Arctic.

2. Your task is to create a survival plan. Discuss and make notes on:
• How will you find water and food?
• How will you build a shelter?
• How will you try to get rescued?
• How will you keep morale high and work together?

3. Next, you will exchange your plan with another group.

4. Read the other group's plan carefully. Can you find any problems or weaknesses? Prepare questions to ask them about their strategy.

tags.teacher_instruction: Divide the class into groups and assign one of the three environments to each. You can start with a quick brainstorm of challenges for each environment as a whole class. The peer-review part of the activity is key for critical thinking and communication.

title: The Unescapable Prison: Design and Breakout
full_description:
This is an exercise in system design and problem-solving.

Part 1: Design the Prison
1. In your group, design a high-security prison that is almost impossible to escape from.
2. Create a simple plan of the building and a daily schedule for the prisoners (e.g., exercise time, meals, lights out).

Part 2: Plan the Escape
1. Exchange your prison plan with another group.
2. Your new task is to analyze their prison and find a way to escape.

Part 3: The Secret Meeting
1. Pair up with a student from the other group. One of you is the prisoner, and the other is a visitor.
2. Role-play the conversation where you secretly discuss the escape plan.

tags.teacher_instruction: Note: This topic can be sensitive. Frame it clearly as a fictional problem-solving challenge about systems and creative thinking, not a realistic portrayal of prison life. Monitor group discussions to ensure they remain appropriate.

title: Wilderness Survival Project
full_description:
For this project, you will become an expert on one survival skill.

1. For homework, use the internet to research one specific 'wilderness survival skill'. Examples include:
• How to build a fire without matches.
• How to find safe water to drink.
• How to build a simple emergency shelter.
• How to navigate using the sun or stars.

2. Make notes on the most important steps for your chosen skill.

3. In our next class, you will get into groups and share what you have learned. Teach your skill to your group members.

title: Binge-Watching: TV and Streaming Today
full_description:
Let's talk about the shows and series we watch.

1. With a partner, try to describe a popular TV show or series (like *SKAM*, *Stranger Things*, *The Office*) without saying its name. See if your partner can guess it.

2. In groups, brainstorm a list of different types of TV/streaming genres. For example:
• Reality TV
• Police dramas / Crime
• Comedy series
• Nature documentaries
• Talk shows

3. On your own, rank the list of genres from your most favourite to your least favourite.

4. Compare your ranking with your group. Which genres are most popular? Do you have similar tastes?

tags.teacher_instruction: Begin by asking the class what streaming services they use (Netflix, HBO, NRK TV, etc.) and what shows are popular right now. Use their suggestions to create a relevant list of examples for the guessing game. The original list of shows from 2003 is very outdated.

title: Class Survey: Our Media Habits
full_description:
Let's find out about the media habits of our class!

1. Your teacher will give you one question.

2. Your task is to 'mingle' - walk around the classroom and ask every student your question. Keep a tally of their answers.

3. Once everyone is finished, we will go around the class. Take turns reading out your question and sharing the results of your survey.

4. For example: 'I asked the class if they watch series with subtitles. 80% said yes.'

tags.teacher_instruction: Dictate one of the following modernized questions to each student: How many hours a week do you watch series/YouTube? Do you follow any series regularly? How often do you watch English-language content? What is your favourite show right now? Is there too much violence in movies/games? Should ads targeted at children on YouTube be banned? Do you get most of your news from social media? Which app do you use most for entertainment?

title: Create an Ad Campaign
full_description:
Let's become an advertising agency for a day!

1. First, discuss with a partner: What are your favourite or least favourite ads you've seen recently (on TV, TikTok, YouTube, etc.)? Do you think ads influence you?

2. In small groups, your task is to design an advertising campaign for one of the following products:
• A new video game
• A sustainable fashion brand
• A new energy drink
• An electric scooter
• A new mobile app

3. Plan your campaign. Think about: Who is your target audience? What is your main message? Will it be a short video for social media, a poster, or something else?

4. Prepare a short presentation to 'pitch' your campaign to the rest of the class, who will act as your clients.

title: Media Challenge: News Headlines & Shared Viewing
full_description:
This project has two parts. Your teacher will assign one to your group.

Option 1: News Headlines
1. For homework, follow one major news story for a day. You can use any source: TV news, online newspapers (like VG, Aftenposten), or news feeds on social media.
2. Take notes on the key events and information.
3. Turn your notes into three short, powerful headlines for the story.
4. In class, get into groups and compare your headlines. How similar or different are they?

Option 2: Plan Your Viewing
1. For homework, look at the guide for a streaming service (like Netflix, HBO, or NRK TV).
2. In your group, you must agree on a plan for one evening of viewing. Imagine you can only watch one screen together and cannot watch different things.
3. You must negotiate and compromise to create a schedule that everyone can agree on.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity requires homework. You can assign one option to the whole class or let groups choose. The second option is a pure negotiation and problem-solving task, focusing on practical communication skills.

title: What's Your Relationship With Time?
full_description:
In small groups, discuss your thoughts and habits related to time.

1. Talk about the following questions together:
• Who in your group is the most punctual (always on time)? Who is often late?
• How do you keep track of your appointments and schedule? (e.g., phone calendar, a physical planner, just memory?)
• What is your favourite time of day? What is your favourite time of year? Why?
• What does the expression 'quality time' mean to you? How do you spend your quality time?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity included the terms 'waste of time' and 'leisure society', which can be added for higher-level groups if you want to introduce more abstract concepts.

title: Discussing Sayings About Time
full_description:
In small groups, read the following sayings about time. Discuss what you think each one means. Do you agree or disagree with them? Are there similar sayings in Norwegian?

• Time is a great healer.
• Time is money.
• Time waits for no one.
• Time flies when you're having fun.
• There's no time like the present.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the list of proverbs on the board. Encourage students to connect the meanings to their own experiences. This is a good opportunity to discuss cultural differences in how time is perceived.

title: Interview Your Partner (and Teacher!) About Time
full_description:
1. In pairs, prepare three questions to ask your teacher about how they spend their time. Use these question starters:
• How long does it take you to...?
• How much time do you spend...?
• How many times a week do you...?

2. As a class, you can ask your teacher some of the questions you prepared.

3. Now, use the same types of questions to interview your partner about their daily or weekly routines.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a good, controlled practice for specific question forms. Be prepared to answer some questions about your own routines to model the activity and build rapport. The original instruction noted 'I'll answer any correctly formed questions honestly', which is a good rule to state.

title: Life's Timeline: Milestones and Memories
full_description:
1. In small groups, discuss when you think is the best time in life to do these things. Is there a 'right' age?
• Get married
• Have children
• Leave home
• Travel the world
• Retire from work

2. Next, look at the list of words your teacher gives you. As a group, try to put them in chronological order, from childhood to old age.

3. Finally, on your own, draw a simple graph of your life so far. The line goes up for good periods and down for difficult ones. In pairs, explain your life graph to your partner. You only need to share what you are comfortable with.

tags.teacher_instruction: For step 2, provide this list of words on the board: homework, diapers (nappies), retirement, exams, housework, marriage, parties, acne, responsibility, grey hair, teddy bears. Remind students that for the life graph activity, sharing is optional and they control what details they discuss.

title: Brainstorming and Ranking Transport
full_description:
1. With a partner, share the most unusual form of transport you have ever used.

2. In small groups, brainstorm as many different kinds of transport as you can.

3. As a group, choose a criterion for ranking them (e.g., fastest, most environmentally friendly, most expensive, most dangerous). Rank your list of transport types according to your chosen criterion.

4. Read your ranked list to the class. Can the other groups guess what your criterion was?

tags.teacher_instruction: To extend the activity, you can provide a list of specific transport types for discussion, such as: gondola, tank, hot-air balloon, helicopter, yacht, horse and carriage, electric scooter, double-decker bus, spaceship.

title: Solving City Traffic: A Policy Debate
full_description:
1. As a class, discuss how you travel to school. What are the pros and cons of the public transport system in your area?

2. In small groups, imagine you are the city council for a large, congested city like Oslo. Your city has a big problem with traffic jams and pollution.

3. Your task is to agree on a list of five policies to encourage people to stop using their cars and start using public transport, bikes, or other solutions.

4. Be prepared to present and defend your policies to the rest of the class.

title: Travel Stories & Immigration Role-Play
full_description:
Part 1: Travel Stories
1. In small groups, tell each other about a memorable journey you have taken. It could be a recent trip or one from a long time ago. Talk about where you went, how you travelled, and one interesting thing that happened.

Part 2: Immigration Role-Play
1. In pairs, write some questions that an immigration officer at an airport might ask a traveller. Use question words like: Why? What? Who? Where? How long?
2. Find a new partner. One of you is the passenger, and the other is the immigration officer. Role-play the conversation at passport control.

tags.teacher_instruction: Be aware that the immigration role-play could be a sensitive topic for students with certain backgrounds. Frame it as a language practice activity focused on formal question-and-answer exchanges.

title: All About Cars: Dreams, Driving, and Journeys
full_description:
1. On a piece of paper, write down the model and colour of your dream car, but do not write your name on it. Your teacher will collect the papers and read them out. Try to guess who wrote each one.

2. In groups, discuss your experiences with cars and driving.
• Do you have a driving licence? Was it difficult to get?
• Tell your group about a memorable journey you have taken by car.

tags.teacher_instruction: For the first part, collect the anonymous notes and read them aloud for the guessing game. The original activity also included a discussion on highway codes, which can be added if you want to focus on rules and regulations, but it has been removed here for simplicity.

title: Online Challenge: Find the Best Car Rental Deal
full_description:
For this project, you will practice finding information and comparing offers online.

1. Use the internet to research car rental companies. You can look at international sites (like Hertz, Avis) or Norwegian peer-to-peer services (like Getaround/Nabobil).

2. Your task is to find the best deal for a one-week car rental for a specific type of car (e.g., a small electric car like a VW e-Up!, or a family car like a VW Passat).

3. Pay close attention to the details!
• What is the total price?
• Is there a limit on kilometres?
• What is the cost of insurance?
• Are there any hidden fees?

4. Compare your research with a partner. Who found the best deal?

tags.teacher_instruction: Students will need devices with internet access. This is a great task for developing practical digital literacy. You can set the parameters, e.g., 'Find the best deal for renting a small electric car in Oslo for the first week of July.'

title: Discussing Work: The Good, The Bad, and The Future
full_description:
Let's talk about the world of work.

1. As a class, discuss: Do people in our society spend too much of their lives working?

2. In small groups, tell each other about:
• The best or worst job you have ever had (this could be a summer job or part-time work).
• A job you think would be very interesting.
• A job you think would be very dangerous.

3. Discuss how buying products made in other countries might affect jobs here in Norway.

tags.teacher_instruction: Be aware that topics like work and unemployment can be sensitive for some students or their families. Frame the discussion in general terms.

title: Interviewing Each Other About Work
full_description:
In this activity, you will practice asking and answering questions about a job.

1. First, look at the list of job aspects your teacher shows you (e.g., pay, hours, the boss).

2. As a class, you can ask your teacher some questions about their job using the list for ideas.

3. In pairs, use similar questions to interview your partner about their job. If your partner does not have a job, ask them about a job they would like to have in the future.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write these job aspects on the board to guide student questions: duties, pay, the boss, benefits, training, holidays, health and safety, promotion, hours of work, overtime, job security. Be prepared to answer a few questions about your own job. It's important to provide the alternative for students who are not currently working.

title: Role-Play Debate: The New Factory
full_description:
You are going to participate in a debate about a plan to build a new clothes factory.

1. Your teacher will put you in a group and assign you a specific role.

2. Read your role carefully and think about your character's point of view. Are you for or against the new factory? Why?

3. As a group, take turns introducing your character and explaining your position on the factory.

4. After everyone has spoken, your group must try to negotiate a deal that is the best possible outcome for everyone involved.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a complex role-play for B2+ students. Divide students into groups of 4-6 and assign one of these roles to each student: 1) The CEO of the clothing company (wants low costs). 2) A local politician in the developing country (wants jobs for their community). 3) An environmental activist (worried about pollution). 4) An unemployed local worker (desperately needs a job). 5) A factory worker from the company's home country (worried about losing their job). 6) A journalist covering the story.

title: Can You...? A Classroom Mingle
full_description:
Part 1: Find Someone Who...
1. Mingle around the classroom and ask your classmates if they can do the things on the list your teacher gives you. Try to find a different person for each ability.
2. Keep a note of their answers for a class feedback session afterwards.

Part 2: I Can't, But...
1. Write a short list of things that you cannot do, but that you think someone else in the class can do.
2. Take turns reading out your sentences to see if you are right. For example: 'I can't ski backwards, but I think Ola can.'

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, provide a list of abilities on the board or a handout. Modernize the list with relevant skills, e.g., 'speak another language besides Norwegian/English', 'swim', 'drive', 'cook well', 'play a musical instrument', 'ride a horse', 'solve a Rubik's cube', 'do a cartwheel', 'edit a video'.

title: Finding Our Group's Superpowers
full_description:
Part 1: Our Group's Talents
1. In your group, find out what special abilities or talents you have together. Think about different areas, for example:
• Cooking or baking
• Sports
• Arts, crafts, or drawing
• Music
• Technical skills (e.g., with computers or cars)
• Languages
2. Which group has the most interesting combination of talents?

Part 2: Animal Abilities
1. In pairs, make a list of special abilities that animals have (e.g., 'Eagles can see things from very far away.').
2. Discuss how your life would be different if you had one of these abilities.

title: Grammar Focus: Could vs. Managed To
full_description:
Let's practice the difference between having the general ability in the past ('could') and succeeding in a specific situation ('managed to').

1. Work in pairs. Your teacher will give you some sentence beginnings.

2. For each sentence, finish it in a way that shows you succeeded in a specific, difficult situation. Use 'managed to'.

3. For example:
The car broke down, but we managed to push it to a garage.

4. After you finish, read the beginning of a sentence to your partner and see if they can guess how you finished it.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This activity focuses on a specific grammar point. Provide these sentence stems on the board: 
• Despite losing my key, I...
• I didn't have a life jacket, but I...
• Although I was exhausted,...
• I don't know how to cook, but I...
This activity has been simplified from a more complex original to focus on the key language.

title: Giving Advice: You Should...
full_description:
Part 1: Giving Quick Advice
1. In small groups, take turns giving each other advice for the situations your teacher gives you. Use 'You should...' or 'You ought to...'.

Part 2: Finishing the Tips
1. Your teacher will give you some sentence beginnings. As a group, agree on the best way to finish them and write your ideas down.
2. Swap your completed sentences with another group and see if you agree with their advice.

Part 3: Personal Experience
1. Think about a time you helped someone by giving them good advice. Tell a partner about it.

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, provide situations like: 'I'm bored.', 'My boss shouts at me.', 'I want to get fit.', 'My phone battery always dies.'. For Part 2, provide sentence starters like: 'To be happy in life you should (not)...', 'To learn a language you should (not)...', 'To drive safely you should (not)...'

title: First Aid Scenarios: What Should You Do?
full_description:
In this activity, we will discuss what to do in emergency situations. Remember, the goal is language practice, not a medical course!

1. In pairs, look at the list of medical emergencies from your teacher.

2. Discuss what you think the first and most important thing to do is in each situation. What should you do while you wait for professional help?

tags.teacher_instruction: CRITICAL: Before starting, stress to students that in any real emergency, the first step is to call for professional help (113 in Norway). Provide a list of situations on the board: someone is choking, someone is bleeding heavily, someone has a serious burn, someone might have hypothermia, someone stops breathing, someone has been bitten by a hoggorm (adder). This topic can be sensitive.

title: The Problem Page: Writing and Replying
full_description:
Many newspapers and magazines have a 'problem page' or 'advice column' where people can write in for advice. Let's try it ourselves.

1. In small groups, you will write a letter to an advice columnist. Choose a common life problem to write about (e.g., problems with friends, stress from school, money worries, etc.). Give some details and ask for advice.

2. When you have finished your letter, pass it to another group.

3. Your group will now write a helpful reply to the letter you received.

4. Return the original letter and your reply to the first group. Read the advice you received. Do you think it is good advice? Why or why not?

tags.teacher_instruction: This topic is sensitive. Guide students to choose general, non-personal problems for their letters. You can brainstorm some appropriate topics on the board first, like: 'My friend is always late', 'I have trouble motivating myself for school', 'My parents don't like my taste in music'.

title: Advice Challenge: If I Were You...
full_description:
Let's play a game of giving advice!

1. Your teacher will read out a series of problems.

2. In your group, quickly discuss the problem and agree on one piece of advice.

3. Your advice must start with the phrase: 'If I were you, I would...'

4. Your teacher will listen to the advice from all groups and award a point to the group with the best or most creative suggestion for each problem.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a fun, competitive way to practice the second conditional for giving advice. Read out a list of simple problems, one at a time. Examples: 'I can never find my keys.', 'My neighbours are too noisy.', 'I can't stop hiccuping.', 'My phone bill is huge.', 'My life is boring.'

title: Role-Play: At the Doctor's Office
full_description:
Part 1: What's the Diagnosis?
1. In pairs, look at the list of symptoms from your teacher (e.g., 'I feel tired all the time.'). Discuss what the problem might be and what advice you would give.

Part 2: The Difficult Patient
1. In your pair, one of you is the doctor and one is the patient. You will role-play a conversation in a doctor's office.
2. The doctor should give the patient clear advice.
3. The patient's role is to be a bit difficult. For every piece of advice the doctor gives, the patient should find an excuse for why they can't follow it.
4. For example: Doctor - 'You should stay in bed for three days.' Patient - 'But I have to work, my boss needs me!'
5. Swap roles and try again.

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, provide a list of common symptoms on the board: 'I feel tired all the time.', 'I have a bad cough.', 'I can't get to sleep.', 'I have a sore throat.', 'My back hurts.' Note that health topics can be sensitive.

title: Decoding English Proverbs
full_description:
Proverbs are short, traditional sayings that express a general truth or piece of advice.

1. In pairs, read the English proverbs below. Discuss what you think each one means.
• A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
• You can't judge a book by its cover.
• Too many cooks spoil the broth.
• Every cloud has a silver lining.
• It's no use crying over spilt milk.

2. For each proverb, try to write one sentence explaining its meaning using 'You should...' or 'You shouldn't...'. For example: For 'Too many cooks spoil the broth', you could write: 'You shouldn't have too many people trying to lead a project at the same time.'

3. Can you think of any similar proverbs in Norwegian? Share them with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: Start by explaining what a proverb is. Write the list of proverbs on the board. This activity requires abstract thinking and is best suited for higher-level students. The cultural comparison at the end is a great way to engage the class.

title: The Unbearable Roommate Game
full_description:
Let's play a game about giving advice for bad habits.

1. In your group, brainstorm a list of adjectives to describe an annoying or difficult roommate (e.g., lazy, noisy, messy).

2. Next to each adjective, write a piece of advice you would give to this person. For example, for 'Lazy', you could write: 'You should help clean the kitchen more often.'

3. Now, you will compete against another group. Take turns reading only your advice sentence to the other group.

4. The other group must listen and guess which adjective your advice is for.

tags.teacher_instruction: Divide the class into two large teams or several smaller groups that can compete against each other. The activity is framed around a fictional roommate to keep it light-hearted. It's a fun way to practice adjectives and giving advice with modals like 'should'.

title: Hindsight 20/20: Analysing What Went Wrong
full_description:
In this activity, you'll look at a bad outcome and work backwards to figure out what mistakes were made.

1. Your teacher will give your pair a sentence describing a disastrous situation.

2. Your task is to invent and write down a sequence of five mistakes that led to this disaster.

3. Swap your list of mistakes with another pair.

4. Read the sequence you received. For each mistake, discuss what the person 'should have done' or 'shouldn't have done'. Write down your advice and give it back to the original pair.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices past modals of regret/advice (`should have`). Provide each pair with one of these bad outcomes: 'The holiday was a complete disaster.', 'They got divorced after only six months.', 'The group project received a failing grade.', 'He had to take a long time off work due to stress.' The original activity suggested historical events, which is too sensitive. Stick to these fictional, personal scenarios. Frame it as a creative thinking exercise.

title: Sharing Stories: A Time I'd Do Things Differently
full_description:
We all have moments in life we wish we could do over. This is a chance to share a small story about a regret.

1. On your own, think about something from your past that you wish you had done differently. It can be something small and funny or more serious. It's completely up to you.

2. Write one or two sentences about it. You can start with 'I should never have...' or 'I wish I hadn't...'.

3. In small, trusted groups, take turns sharing your story if you feel comfortable. Your group members can ask you simple questions to learn more about what happened.

tags.teacher_instruction: CRITICAL: This topic is highly sensitive. Before starting, establish clear ground rules. Emphasize that sharing is 100% voluntary. No one should feel pressured to share or to disclose anything they don't want to. Model a light-hearted example yourself, e.g., 'I should never have tried to cut my own hair.'

title: Role-Play: At the Market
full_description:
Let's practice a typical shopping conversation.

Part 1: Preparation
1. In your pair, one person is the Shopkeeper and the other is the Customer.
2. The Shopkeeper writes a list of things they sell at their market stall (e.g., baker, butcher, computer shop).
3. The Customer writes a shopping list of a few items they want to buy.

Part 2: Role-Play
1. Practice a shopping conversation. Use the dialogue below as a model to start.

Example Dialogue:
Customer: Good morning.
Shopkeeper: Good morning. How can I help you?
Customer: I'd like a kilo of onions, please.
Shopkeeper: Here you go. Anything else?
Customer: Yes, I'll have a large beetroot.
Shopkeeper: One large beetroot. Is that everything?
Customer: That's all, thanks.
Shopkeeper: OK. That'll be 45 kroner, please.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the example dialogue on the board. Assign pairs and roles. Let them choose a type of shop from a list you provide: chemist, market stall (fruit/veg), newsagent, butcher, bakery, computer shop, sports shop.

title: How Much Did It Cost? Price Questions
full_description:
In pairs, you will practice asking about the price of items in different ways.

1. Choose an object that you have with you (e.g., a pen, a notebook, your phone case).

2. Ask your partner four different questions about the price of their object, following the pattern below. Your partner should answer each one.

Pattern:
• How much did you buy your [pen] for? (I bought my pen for 30 kr.)
• How much did you pay for your [pen]? (I paid 30 kr for my pen.)
• How much did you spend on your [pen]? (I spent 30 kr on my pen.)
• How much did your [pen] cost? (My pen cost 30 kr.)

3. After asking, for fun, make an offer for their item: 'I'll give you 20 kr for it!'

title: Second-Hand Bargain Hunt Role-Play
full_description:
Have you ever bought or sold something second-hand online, for example on Finn.no or Tise?

This is a role-play about buying and selling used items.

Part 1: Preparation
• Your teacher will put you in a pair and tell you if you are sellers (Pair A) or buyers (Pair B).

Part 2: The Phone Call
• You will then be re-paired with someone from the opposite group (one buyer, one seller).
• Role-play a telephone conversation where the buyer calls about the seller's ad. The buyer should try to get information and negotiate a better price. The seller should try to sell their items for the best price possible.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Divide the class into two halves: Sellers and Buyers. Have them work in pairs first to prepare their lists.
• Sellers (Pair A): You are clearing out a house/apartment. Brainstorm ten items to sell and give each a price (e.g., sofa, gaming chair, bicycle).
• Buyers (Pair B): You are furnishing an empty apartment. Brainstorm ten items you need and decide on a budget for each.
After preparation, re-pair students so each pair has one buyer and one seller for the role-play.

title: The Ultimate Complaint: A Three-Way Role-Play
full_description:
In this activity, you will role-play a conflict in a shop.

1. First, in your group of three, quickly brainstorm a reason to complain at a shop. For example: 'I bought these shoes yesterday and the heel has already broken.'

2. Once you have your complaint, you will role-play the situation. Each person has a specific role:
• Student A: You are the argumentative customer.
• Student B: You are the unhelpful shop assistant.
• Student C: You are the manager, who is called to solve the problem.

tags.teacher_instruction: To start, warm up by calling out different types of shops (e.g., phone repair shop, café, clothing store, supermarket) and having groups quickly shout out a possible complaint. Then, have them choose one complaint for their three-person role-play. The dynamic between the three specific roles is key to the activity.

title: My Real-Life Complaint Story
full_description:
Think about a time you had to complain about a product or service in real life. Maybe the food was cold, or a product you bought was broken.

1. In small groups, tell each other your story. What happened? Were you polite? Did the company solve your problem?

2. As a group, choose the most interesting or funny complaint story.

3. Together, write a short script of the conversation that happened.

4. Be prepared to read your script out loud to the class.

title: Mini-Dialogues: Wrong Item Complaint
full_description:
Imagine you are in a shop complaining because the sales assistant gave you the wrong item.

1. In pairs, write a short two-line dialogue for the situations your teacher gives you.

2. Use the example below as a model.
Example pair: 'size 42 / size 44'
• Customer: Excuse me, I asked for a size 42, but you gave me a 44.
• Assistant: Oh, I'm terribly sorry about that. I'll get you the right size.

3. When you are finished, swap dialogues with another pair and practice reading them out loud.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Provide pairs with a list of mix-ups to base their dialogues on. Use modern, relevant examples:
• regular latte / oat milk latte
• wired headphones / wireless headphones
• brown bread / white bread
• iPhone charger / Android charger
• 100 kr note / 200 kr note (as change)

title: Roommate Conflict Role-Play
full_description:
Imagine you are two people sharing an apartment or a dorm room. You have very different personalities and habits, and it's causing problems.

1. Your teacher will assign you a role: Student A (the tidy one) or Student B (the messy one).

2. In your pair, role-play a conversation where you discuss your problems. Try to give each other advice or make suggestions for how to live together more peacefully.

For example:
Student A: 'You shouldn't leave your dirty clothes on the floor.'
Student B: 'Why don't you relax a bit? You worry too much.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
Assign roles to students in each pair.
• Student A: You are very tidy and organized. You like peace and quiet to study. You always pay bills on time and do most of the housework.
• Student B: You are very messy and untidy. You like loud music and having friends over. You hate cooking and housework and are often broke.

title: Guess the Location from the Complaint
full_description:
Let's play a guessing game!

1. I am going to read a series of complaints out loud.

2. After you hear each complaint, discuss with your partner and write down where you think I am.

3. After each one, we will see who guessed correctly!

4. At the end, you can work in your pair to write two more complaints for the class to guess.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Read the following modernized complaints to the class one by one. The answers are in brackets.
1. 'This coffee is cold and the Wi-Fi password you gave me doesn't work.' (Café)
2. 'Typical! You wait for 20 minutes and then two come along at the same time!' (Bus stop)
3. 'The screen on my phone is still cracked, but you charged me 1000 kroner for the repair.' (Phone repair shop)
4. 'I ordered this online two weeks ago and the tracking information still hasn't updated.' (Online shopping / Talking to customer service)
5. 'Excuse me, I asked for this burger with no onions.' (Restaurant / Fast food place)

title: Word Detective: A Logic Game
full_description:
Let's play a word-guessing game. It is like the game Mastermind or Wordle.

1. I am thinking of a secret five-letter English word.

2. You (as a class or in groups) will suggest a five-letter word as a guess.

3. For each guess, I will give you a code:
• I will say 'X' for every letter that is correct AND in the correct position.
• I will say 'O' for every letter that is correct but in the WRONG position.

4. Use the codes to deduce the secret word. For example, if the secret word is 'WRITE' and you guess 'PAPER', I will say 'One O' (for the 'R'). If you guess 'PROVE', I will say 'One X' (for the 'R').

tags.teacher_instruction: This game requires logical deduction. Prepare a few common five-letter English words in advance (e.g., WATER, HOUSE, STUDY, OTHER, NIGHT). Do one demonstration round with the whole class, writing the guesses and the X/O codes on the board to make the process clear. The original instructions were very complex; this simplified version is easier to follow.

title: Guess the Drawing: Line by Line
full_description:
Let's play a guessing game with drawings!

1. Your teacher (or a student volunteer) will start to draw an object on the board, one single line at a time.

2. After each line is drawn, you can try to guess what the final picture will be.

3. Use phrases for guessing, like:
• 'It might be a...'
• 'It could be a...'
• 'Is it a...?'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a fun, low-prep warmer. Model the target language ('It might be a...'). Have a list of simple-to-draw objects ready. Examples: bicycle, house, car, cat, tree, sunglasses, coffee cup, guitar.

title: Making Deductions: Present and Past
full_description:
In this activity, you will practice making logical guesses (deductions) about different situations.

Part 1: Present Situations
1. Your teacher will describe a situation happening now. With your partner, discuss possible explanations. Use 'He might be...', 'She must be...', 'Maybe...'.

Part 2: Past Situations
1. Next, your teacher will describe a situation that has already happened. With your partner, discuss what could have happened. Use 'He must have...', 'They can't have...'.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Provide students with situations one by one. 
Present Situations: 
• The phone is ringing, but he isn't answering. 
• There's a lot of noise coming from next door. 
• Your classmate is always smiling these days. 
• The car won't start.
Past Situations:
• Your friend has a great tan, even though it's winter.
• The boss looks really tired this morning.
• They came back from their holiday looking very disappointed.
• My phone rang at three o'clock this morning.

title: Mystery Morning: What Happened Last Night?
full_description:
Imagine you wake up one morning and things are very strange. You can't remember anything from the night before, but you discover some clues.

In your small group, look at the list of clues below. Speculate about what might have happened. Try to create a story that explains all the clues.

Here are the clues:
• There's a strange phone number with the letters 'CS' written on your hand.
• There's a half-eaten kebab on the kitchen counter, but you are a vegetarian.
• You have a small scratch on your forehead.
• The front door is wide open.
• Your photo is on the front page of the local online newspaper (e.g., VG).

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a creative problem-solving activity. The original context implies a hangover. To make it more appropriate, frame it as a 'strange mystery morning' scenario. The clues are deliberately ambiguous to encourage creative storytelling. Monitor groups to ensure discussions remain light-hearted.

title: Classroom Crime Scene: Who Did It?
full_description:
A terrible crime has been committed: the beloved class mascot has been stolen! The thief must be someone in this classroom.

In your groups, you will act as detectives. Your teacher will reveal clues one by one.

After each clue, discuss who the thief might be, or who it can't be. Use language of deduction like:
• 'It can't be [student's name] because...'
• 'It might be [student's name] because...'
• 'The thief must be someone who...'

At the end, each group must present their final accusation!

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a fun deduction game. To avoid the sensitivity of a 'murder', the crime has been changed to a stolen class mascot (a plant, a stuffed animal, etc.). Reveal the clues on the board one at a time:
1. A half-eaten Snickers bar was found at the scene. The mascot's owner is allergic to nuts.
2. There was a ransom note, but it contained several English grammar mistakes.
3. Forensic evidence suggests the thief has blonde hair.
4. Forensic evidence suggests the thief was wearing a black hoodie.
(Adjust clues to fit your class demographics to ensure there are a few suspects).

title: Think Outside the Box: Logic Puzzles
full_description:
Let's try to solve some logic puzzles that require creative thinking (lateral thinking).

1. I will read a strange situation to you.

2. Your job is to figure out the logical explanation for what happened.

3. You can only ask me questions that can be answered with 'yes' or 'no'.

4. For example: 'Was the man alone?' (Yes/No). 'Why did he leave?' (Not a yes/no question).

tags.teacher_instruction:
These puzzles are challenging. Model the yes/no question process first. The puzzles often involve death, so be mindful of your class. 
Puzzle 1: A man went to a party and drank some of the punch. He then left early. Everyone else at the party who drank the punch subsequently died of poisoning. Why didn't he die? (Answer: The poison was in the ice cubes. The man drank the punch before the ice had melted.)
Puzzle 2: A man is found dead in a field. He is clutching a broken match. What happened? (Answer: He was in a hot air balloon with other people that was losing height. They drew matches to see who had to jump out to save the others. He drew the short match.)

title: Evidence and Deduction
full_description:
This activity is the reverse of what we usually do. I will give you the deduction, and you have to give me the evidence!

For example, if I say:
'They must be in love.'

You could say:
'Because they are smiling at each other and holding hands.'

Let's try a few!

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a quick, oral drill to practice justifying deductions. Read out the deduction sentences one by one and elicit possible evidence from the class. Here are the sentences to use:
• He must have left in a hurry.
• There can't have been anyone at home.
• You must have cooked it at the wrong temperature.
• The thief must have gotten in through the window.
• There must have been a party here last night.

title: Role-Play: Shopping Scenarios
full_description:
Let's practice the language we use for shopping.

1. In pairs, choose a type of shop. For example: a clothing store, an electronics shop, a bakery, or a car parts store (`bildeler`).

2. Decide who is the shopkeeper and who is the customer.
• The shopkeeper writes a short list of items they sell.
• The customer writes a short shopping list.

3. Use the example dialogue below to practice a conversation. Try to make it natural!

Example Dialogue:
Customer: Good morning.
Shopkeeper: Good morning. How can I help you?
Customer: I'm looking for a new hoodie.
Shopkeeper: We have some over here. What size do you need?
Customer: A medium, please.
Shopkeeper: Here you go. Anything else?
Customer: No, that's all, thanks.
Shopkeeper: OK. That will be 500 kroner, please.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is for practicing functional transactional language. Provide a list of relevant shop types for vocational students on the board to help them get started.

title: Grammar Drill: Talking About Prices
full_description:
In pairs, you will practice asking about prices using four different verb patterns.

1. Choose an object you have with you (like a pen, a phone, or a notebook).

2. Ask your partner four questions about the price of their item, following the pattern below exactly. Your partner should answer each question.

Pattern:
• How much did you buy your [pen] for? (I bought my pen for 30 kroner.)
• How much did you pay for your [pen]? (I paid 30 kroner for my pen.)
• How much did you spend on your [pen]? (I spent 30 kroner on my pen.)
• How much did your [pen] cost? (My pen cost 30 kroner.)

3. After you finish the questions, make a fun offer for the item: 'I'll give you 20 kroner for it!' Then swap roles.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a focused grammar drill, not a free-flowing conversation. The repetition is intentional to help students memorize the different verb patterns associated with price.

title: Role-Play: Buying and Selling on Finn.no
full_description:
Have you ever bought or sold something second-hand online, for example on Finn.no or Tise? This role-play simulates that experience.

Part 1: Preparation
1. Your teacher will assign your pair a role: either 'Sellers' or 'Buyers'.
2. Sellers: You are clearing out an apartment. Make a list of ten items you want to sell and decide on a price for each.
3. Buyers: You are moving into an empty apartment. Make a list of ten items you need to buy and set a budget for each one.

Part 2: The Phone Call
1. You will now be paired with a student from the opposite group (one buyer, one seller).
2. Role-play a phone conversation. The buyer calls about the seller's ad. The buyer should ask for more information and try to negotiate a lower price. The seller should try to get the best price possible.

tags.teacher_instruction: The information gap is key here. First, divide the class into two halves, Buyers and Sellers. Let them prepare their lists in pairs. Then, create new pairs, ensuring each has one Buyer and one Seller, for the role-play.

title: Role-Play: The Difficult Customer
full_description:
In this activity, you will role-play a conflict in a shop.

1. First, in your group of three, quickly brainstorm a reason to complain at a shop. For example: 'I bought this video game yesterday and the disc is scratched.'

2. Once you have your complaint, you will role-play the situation. Each person has a specific role:
• Student A: You are the angry customer.
• Student B: You are the unhelpful shop assistant.
• Student C: You are the manager, who is called to solve the problem peacefully.

tags.teacher_instruction: To warm up, you can call out different types of shops (e.g., phone repair shop, café, clothing store) and have groups quickly shout out a possible complaint. The three specific roles are what create the dynamic for this activity.

title: Tell Us Your Complaint Story
full_description:
Think about a time in real life when you had to complain about a product or service. Maybe the food at a restaurant was cold, a product you bought online was broken, or a service was not what you expected.

1. In small groups, take turns telling your story. What happened? How did you handle it? Was the problem solved?

2. As a group, choose the most interesting or funny complaint story you heard.

3. Together, write a short script of the conversation that happened.

4. Be prepared to read your script out loud to the class.

title: Role-Play: The Wrong Item
full_description:
Imagine you are in a shop complaining because the sales assistant gave you the wrong item.

1. In pairs, write a short two-line dialogue for the situations your teacher gives you. Use the example below as a model.

Example Situation: 'regular cola / cola zero'
• Customer: Excuse me, I asked for a regular cola, but you gave me a cola zero.
• Assistant: Oh, I'm so sorry. Let me get the right one for you.

2. When you are finished, swap dialogues with another pair and practice reading them out loud.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Provide pairs with a list of modern mix-ups to base their dialogues on:
• iPhone charger / Android charger
• wired headphones / wireless headphones
• brown bread / white bread (grovbrød/loff)
• oat milk latte / regular latte

title: The Roommate Conflict: A Role-Play
full_description:
Imagine you are two students sharing an apartment (`hybel`). You have very different personalities and habits, and it's causing problems.

1. Your teacher will assign you a role: Student A (the tidy one) or Student B (the messy one).

2. In your pair, role-play a conversation where you discuss your problems. Try to give each other advice or make suggestions for how to live together more peacefully.

For example:
Student A: 'You should really wash your dishes after you eat.'
Student B: 'Why don't you relax a bit? I'll do it later.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
Assign roles to students in each pair.
• Student A: You are very tidy and organized. You like peace and quiet to study. You do most of the housework.
• Student B: You are very messy and untidy. You like loud music and having friends over. You hate cooking and cleaning.

title: Guess the Location: Complaint Edition
full_description:
Let's play a guessing game!

1. I am going to read a series of complaints out loud.

2. After you hear each complaint, discuss with your partner and write down where you think the speaker is.

3. After each one, we will see who guessed correctly!

4. At the end, you can work in your pair to write your own complaint for the class to guess.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a listening activity. Read the following modernized complaints to the class one by one. The answers are in brackets.
1. 'This Wi-Fi is so slow, and my coffee is cold.' (Café)
2. 'Typical! You wait 20 minutes for the T-bane, and then two come at once!' (Subway station)
3. 'The screen protector you just put on my phone already has bubbles under it.' (Phone repair shop)
4. 'I ordered this online two weeks ago, and the tracking app still says 'in transit'.' (Online shopping customer service)
5. 'Excuse me, I asked for this burger with no onions.' (Restaurant/fast food place)

title: Word Logic Puzzle (Like Wordle)
full_description:
Let's play a word-guessing game that is like Wordle or Mastermind.

1. I am thinking of a secret five-letter English word.

2. As a class, you will suggest a five-letter word as a guess.

3. For each guess, I will give you a code:
• An 'X' for every letter that is correct AND in the correct position.
• An 'O' for every letter that is correct but in the WRONG position.

4. Use the codes from each guess to figure out the secret word!

tags.teacher_instruction: This game requires logical deduction. Do one clear example on the board first. For example, if the secret word is 'WATER' and the first guess is 'BREAD', you would say 'One X (for the E), one O (for the R)'. Prepare a few common five-letter English words in advance (e.g., HOUSE, STUDY, NIGHT, OTHER).

title: Pictionary Guessing Game
full_description:
Let's play a guessing game with drawings!

1. Your teacher (or a student volunteer) will start to draw an object on the board, one single line at a time.

2. After each line is drawn, you can try to guess what the final picture will be.

3. Use these phrases for guessing:
• 'It might be a...'
• 'It could be a...'
• 'Is it a...?'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a fun, low-prep warmer. Model the target language ('It might be a...', 'It could be a...') before starting. Have a list of simple objects ready to draw (e.g., bicycle, house, car, cat, coffee cup, guitar, sunglasses).

title: Deduction Practice: Present and Past
full_description:
In this activity, you will practice making logical guesses (deductions) about different situations.

Part 1: Present Situations
Your teacher will describe a situation happening now. With your partner, discuss possible explanations. Use modals like 'He might be...', 'She must be...', or 'Maybe...'.

Part 2: Past Situations
Next, your teacher will describe a situation that has already happened. With your partner, discuss what could have happened. Use modals like 'He must have...', 'They can't have...', or 'Maybe they...'.

tags.teacher_instruction:
Provide students with situations one by one. 
Present Situations: 
• The phone is ringing, but he isn't answering. 
• There's a lot of noise coming from next door. 
• The car won't start.
Past Situations:
• Your friend has a great tan, even though it's winter.
• The boss looks really tired this morning.
• My phone rang at three o'clock this morning.

title: The Mystery Morning: What Happened?
full_description:
Imagine you wake up one morning and things are very strange. You can't remember anything from the night before, but you discover some clues.

In your small group, look at the list of clues below. Speculate about what might have happened. Try to create a story that explains all the clues.

Here are the clues:
• There's an unknown phone number with the letters 'CS' written on your hand.
• There's a half-eaten kebab on the kitchen counter, but you are a vegetarian.
• You have a small scratch on your forehead.
• The front door is wide open.
• Your photo is on the front page of VG.no.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a creative problem-solving activity. The original context implies a hangover. Frame it as a 'strange mystery morning' scenario to keep it light-hearted. The clues are deliberately ambiguous to encourage creative storytelling. Note the sensitivity warning.

title: The Case of the Stolen Mascot
full_description:
A terrible crime has been committed: the beloved class mascot has been stolen! The thief must be someone in this classroom.

In your groups, you will act as detectives. Your teacher will reveal clues one by one.

After each clue, discuss who the thief might be, or who it can't be. Use language of deduction like:
• 'It can't be [student's name] because...'
• 'It might be [student's name] because...'
• 'The thief must be someone who...'

At the end, each group must present their final accusation and explain their reasoning!

tags.teacher_instruction:
To avoid the sensitivity of a 'murder mystery', the crime has been changed to a stolen class mascot (a plant, a toy, etc.). Reveal the clues on the board one by one. Adjust clues to fit your class demographics so there are a few possible suspects. For example:
1. A Smash chocolate bar wrapper was found at the scene.
2. The thief left a note with English grammar mistakes.
3. A strand of light-colored hair was found.
4. The thief was wearing a black hoodie.

title: Yes/No Logic Puzzles
full_description:
Let's try to solve some logic puzzles that require creative 'outside the box' thinking.

1. I will read a strange situation to you.

2. Your job, as a class, is to figure out the single correct explanation for what happened.

3. To get information, you can only ask me questions that can be answered with 'yes' or 'no'. For example, 'Was the man alone?' is a good question. 'Why did he leave?' is not.

Let's begin with the first puzzle.

tags.teacher_instruction:
These puzzles are challenging and often have dark themes. Be mindful of your class. Model the yes/no question process carefully.
Puzzle 1: A man went to a party and drank some of the punch. He then left early. Everyone else at the party who drank the punch subsequently died of poisoning. Why didn't he die? (Answer: The poison was in the ice cubes. The man drank the punch before the ice had melted.)

title: Justify the Deduction
full_description:
This activity is the reverse of what we usually do. I will give you a deduction (a conclusion), and you have to provide the evidence that supports it!

For example, if I say:
'They must be in love.'

You could say:
'Because they are smiling at each other and holding hands.'

Let's try a few. Listen to my sentence and give me a reason why it must be true.

tags.teacher_instruction:
This is a fast-paced oral drill. Read out the deduction sentences one by one and elicit possible evidence from the class. Here are the sentences:
• He must have left in a hurry.
• There can't have been anyone at home.
• You must have cooked it at the wrong temperature.
• The thief must have gotten in through the window.
• There must have been a party here last night.

title: Describing People: Appearance & Personality
full_description:
1. Your teacher will dictate a list of words. Write them down and categorize them into three groups: 'Hair/Face', 'Build', and 'Personality'.

2. The list of words is: tall, straight, thin, handsome, short, long, blue, beautiful, blond, medium height, curly, pretty, nice, smart, wavy.

3. Next, write a short description of a famous person or a character from a movie or TV show. Do not write the person's name.

4. Your teacher will collect the descriptions and read them aloud. The rest of the class will guess who you described!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original task involved describing a classmate, which can be sensitive. It has been changed to describing a famous person or fictional character to ensure a positive and comfortable environment. When reading the descriptions, foster a fun, game-like atmosphere. Ensure a wide variety of adjectives are understood, particularly the difference between objective descriptions and subjective opinions.

title: Creative Characters: Design and Describe
full_description:
1. In small groups, your task is to design a unique alien or fantasy creature. The more creative and unusual, the better!

2. Give your character a name, special abilities, and a backstory. One person in the group should draw the character based on your group's description.

3. Prepare a short presentation to describe your character to the class. Use descriptive adjectives for its appearance and personality.

4. As each group presents, the rest of the class should listen carefully and try to draw the character based on the description they hear.

5. After each presentation, the presenting group will show their original drawing. Compare the drawings and see which description was the clearest!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity included a section about describing the 'perfect man/woman,' which has been removed as it is highly sensitive and promotes stereotypes. This revised version focuses solely on creativity and descriptive language in a fun, imaginative context.

title: Mystery Object Guessing Game
full_description:
Part 1: The Mystery Bag
1. Your teacher has a bag with mystery objects inside. One student will put their hand in the bag without looking.
2. The student will describe the object they are feeling to the class. For example: 'It feels hard and smooth. It's rectangular and thin.'
3. The rest of the class will try to guess what the object is. After a few guesses, the student will show the object to the class.

Part 2: What is it?
1. In pairs, one student thinks of an everyday object you both know (like a smartphone, a key, or headphones).
2. The other student must guess the object by asking only 'yes/no' questions. You can ask about:
• size
• material
• color
• cost
• when/where you use it

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, collect some simple, common objects from students before the activity begins and add a few of your own to ensure variety. Examples: keys, a phone case, a pen, a small ball, a wallet. Ensure students use descriptive adjectives beyond just color and size.

title: Describing Layouts: Shapes and Prepositions
full_description:
1. First, let's review prepositions of place. Where do these words fit?
• at the top / at the bottom
• on the left / on the right
• in the middle / in the corner

2. Now, let's practice with a game of tic-tac-toe (noughts and crosses). In two teams, tell your teacher where to put your 'X' or 'O' by describing the location, for example: 'Put the X in the top left corner.' You cannot point!

3. Look at the shapes your teacher draws on the board (e.g., square, circle, triangle). Listen as your teacher describes a picture made of shapes, and try to draw it.

4. In pairs, you will get a picture with shapes. Describe it to your partner, who will try to draw it without looking at your picture. Then, swap roles.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity combines several parts from the original. Prepare simple shape-based drawings beforehand for the pair work. For tic-tac-toe, a 3x3 grid on the board is sufficient. This is great practice for giving clear, precise instructions, a key vocational skill.

title: Cross-Cultural Communication: Understanding Gestures
full_description:
In many countries, people use gestures to communicate without words. But be careful – a friendly gesture in one country might mean something different in another!

1. In small groups, discuss how you would use your hands, face, or body to show the following ideas in Norway:
• Hello / Goodbye
• I don't know
• Excellent! or Well done!
• Come here
• I'm thinking
• Good luck

2. Do you know of any gestures from other countries or cultures for these ideas? Share them with your group.

3. Afterwards, we will discuss as a class. Be ready to demonstrate and explain your gestures.

tags.teacher_instruction: Frame this as a discovery activity, not a test. The goal is to raise cultural awareness. Emphasize that being aware of gestural differences is a useful skill in a global workplace. Steer the discussion to be respectful and curious.

title: Mime Challenge: Guess the Object
full_description:
Let's play a guessing game using only actions!

1. One student will get a secret word for an object from the teacher.

2. This student will stand at the front and mime using the object. They cannot speak!

3. Their partner (or the whole class) will try to guess what they are doing by describing their actions. For example: 'You are holding something small. You are typing on it with your thumbs. You are looking down at a screen.'

4. Keep describing and guessing until someone gets the correct object. For example: 'It's a smartphone!'

tags.teacher_instruction: Prepare a list of modern objects on slips of paper. The original list was outdated (camcorder, telephone directory). Good examples for today: drone, VR headset, electric scooter, air fryer, laptop, power bank, wireless headphones. This activity is excellent for practicing the present continuous tense ('You are opening...').

title: Mirror Pose: Giving Clear Instructions
full_description:
This activity is about giving very clear instructions. You will work in groups of three (Student A, B, and C).

1. Students A and B stand back-to-back so they cannot see each other.

2. Student A strikes a simple, neutral pose. It could be an action from a sport, a job, or an everyday activity (e.g., holding a steering wheel, casting a fishing rod).

3. Student C looks at Student A and gives verbal instructions to Student B. Student C must describe the pose exactly so Student B can copy it. For example: 'Lift your right arm. Bend your elbow. Make a fist.'

4. Student B must listen carefully and try to mirror Student A's pose without looking.

5. When the instructions are finished, Students A and B can turn around and compare poses. Then, switch roles!

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity included potentially problematic poses like 'dictator' or 'supermodel'. This version is reframed to focus on neutral, action-based poses. Before starting, advise students to choose poses they are comfortable with and that are appropriate for the classroom. Themes could include 'Sports', 'Workplace Actions', or 'Daily Routines'.

title: Spot the Difference: Describing Categories
full_description:
1. In pairs, discuss the differences between the items in each group below. Describe their function, appearance, or what they are used for.

Group 1: Smartphone, Tablet, Laptop, Smartwatch
Group 2: Welder, Carpenter, Electrician, Plumber
Group 3: Bus, Train, T-bane (Metro), Ferry
Group 4: Hoodie, T-shirt, Sweater, Jacket

2. After you have discussed in pairs, join another pair to form a group of four.

3. In your new group, discuss which item you prefer from each category and explain why.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original word lists were outdated or potentially unfamiliar. The lists have been updated to be more relevant to Norwegian vocational students' lives and studies. Encourage students to use comparative and superlative adjectives in their discussions (e.g., 'A laptop is more powerful than a tablet, but a smartphone is the most portable').

title: What's It Called? Describing an Unknown Object
full_description:
Imagine you are trying to buy something, but you have forgotten the English word for it! This is a role-play activity in pairs.

1. One student is the 'Customer', the other is the 'Shop Assistant'.

2. The teacher will give the Customer the name of an object. The Customer's job is to describe the object to the Shop Assistant without using its name.

3. Use phrases to describe its shape, size, material, and what it's used for. For example: 'I'm looking for one of those things... it's a small box you use to charge your phone when you're not near a socket.'

4. The Shop Assistant listens and tries to guess the object. For example: 'Ah, you mean a power bank!'

5. Swap roles and try with a new object.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of objects was outdated. Prepare slips of paper with modern, relevant objects. Good examples: power bank, wireless earbuds, USB-C cable, HDMI cable, reusable water bottle, Allen key (inbusnøkkel), screwdriver, laptop stand. This is an excellent activity for practicing circumlocution (describing something when you don't know the word).

title: My Favourite Place: Describing and Writing
full_description:
1. In pairs, take turns describing one of the following places to your partner. Use as many details as possible. Think about what you see, hear, and feel there.
• Your favourite room in your house
• Your ideal workshop or studio
• Your home town or neighbourhood
• Your favourite place in nature (e.g., a forest, a mountain, the coast)
• Your favourite place in a video game

2. After you have talked with your partner, choose one of these places.

3. Write a short description of it (about 100 words). Try to use vivid adjectives to make your description interesting.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a straightforward descriptive activity. The prompts have been slightly updated to include options more relevant to teenagers' interests (workshop, video game world). Encourage students to use sensory details in their descriptions.

title: Writing Haiku: Capturing a Moment in 5-7-5
full_description:
A haiku is a short, three-line poem from Japan. It's a great way to capture a single moment or feeling. The structure is simple:
• The first line has 5 syllables.
• The second line has 7 syllables.
• The third line has 5 syllables.

Example about school:
Green screen full of text
My fingers fly on the keys
New code comes to life
(5)
(7)
(5)

1. In pairs, write two haiku poems. You can write about:
• A moment from your school day or work placement
• Your favourite hobby
• A season or the weather today

2. When you are finished, you can share your favourite haiku with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: The concept of syllables can be tricky. Model counting syllables with a few example words and lines on the board. The original focused on nature; this version broadens the topics to make it more accessible and relevant to vocational students' experiences.

title: Prepositions in Action: Classroom Commands
full_description:
This is a physical activity to practice prepositions of place and direction.

1. First, in your notebook, sort these words into two groups: 'Place' (where something is) and 'Direction' (where something is going). Some words might fit in both!
Words: through, down, across, along, into, below, up, out, between, in, around, over, opposite, under, on, off

2. Now, work in pairs. Take turns giving your partner simple commands using these prepositions. Your partner must do the action.
For example:
• 'Put your pen *on* your head.'
• 'Walk *around* your desk.'
• 'Hide your phone *under* your book.'

3. Try to use at least five different prepositions.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity was a static dictionary task. This version makes it active and communicative (kinesthetic), which can improve engagement and retention. Ensure the classroom has enough space for students to move a little. Keep the commands simple and safe.

title: Map Your Ideal Neighbourhood
full_description:
1. First, discuss in pairs: What makes a great neighbourhood to live in? Think about shops, transport, nature, and other facilities. Who has the best access to these things where they live now?

2. Next, you will design your own ideal neighbourhood block. On a piece of paper, draw a simple street plan.

3. Decide where to put these places on your map. You can add other places too!
• A bakery or café
• A bus or T-bane stop
• A park or green space
• A grocery store (e.g., Kiwi, Rema 1000)
• A gym or sports facility
• A workshop or library

4. Form a group with another pair. Do not show them your map! Describe your ideal neighbourhood to them. They will ask you questions to find out what is on your map and where things are located.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity has been updated to be more creative and localized. Instead of copying a pre-set plan, students design their own, which allows for more personalization. Encourage the use of Norwegian-specific examples (T-bane, specific store names) to ground the activity in their reality.

title: My Journey: Describing and Comparing Routes
full_description:
Part 1: The Journey to School
1. In small groups, discuss your daily journey to school. How do you get here? What do you see on the way?
2. Find out whose journey is the longest or most complicated. One person in the group (the secretary) should write a short description of that journey.
3. The secretary will read the description to the class. We will find out who in the class has the most difficult journey to school!

Part 2: Giving Directions
1. In pairs, one student will give directions from a well-known local landmark (like the main train station or a shopping centre) to the school.
