2. The other student will listen and can ask questions if the directions are unclear. You can try to draw a simple map as you listen.
3. Is the journey complicated? How many changes do you need to make?

tags.teacher_instruction: The original activity included a debate about city vs. countryside living, which has been removed to focus the activity on the practical skill of describing routes. Having a digital map (like Google Maps) of the local area visible on a smartboard can be very helpful for Part 2.

title: Get to Know You: Profile Exchange
full_description:
1. Copy this simple profile form into your notebook:
• Name:
• Three things I enjoy:
• Three things I don't enjoy:
• A skill I'm proud of:
• Future goal or dream:

2. Work in pairs. Ask your partner questions to fill in the form about them. For example: 'What's a skill you are proud of?'

3. When you are done, swap forms and check that the information your partner wrote about you is correct.

4. Now, join another pair to make a group of four. Look at each other's profiles and ask follow-up questions to learn more about each other. For example: 'It says here your future goal is to be a web developer. What kind of websites do you want to build?'

tags.teacher_instruction: The original form included fields like 'Marital status' and 'Children,' which are not appropriate for this age group. The form has been updated to be more relevant and comfortable for VG1 students. Remind students they only have to share information they feel comfortable sharing.

title: Two Truths and a Lie
full_description:
This is a fun game to get to know your classmates better.

1. First, think of three statements about yourself. Two of them must be true, and one of them must be a lie. Make the lie believable!

For example:
• I have traveled to Asia.
• I can play the guitar.
• My favourite food is pizza.

2. Work in small groups of 3-4 people. Take turns sharing your three statements.

3. The other students in the group can ask you questions about your statements to find out more details.

4. After asking questions, the group must vote on which statement they think is the lie. Then, reveal the truth! The goal is to successfully fool your group members.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic ELT game. It is a good idea to model the activity yourself first. Share your own two truths and a lie, let students ask you questions, and then let them guess. This makes the rules very clear.

title: Creative Introductions: Alliteration Game
full_description:
Let's introduce ourselves in a creative way! The goal is to use alliteration (words that start with the same sound).

1. Think of an adjective that describes you and a thing that you like (a noun). Both words must start with the same first letter as your first name.

2. We will go around the class in a circle. Each person will introduce themselves.

For example:
• 'I'm Musical Martin and I like motorcycles.'
• 'I'm Happy Hanna and I like horses.'
• 'I'm Brilliant Bjørn and I like building.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity was simplified from the original to remove a stressful memory game component. This version is a fun, low-pressure icebreaker that encourages creativity and practices adjectives. Give students a minute to think before you start.

title: Character Profiles: Making Inferences
full_description:
In this activity, you will practice making guesses (inferences) about people based on a short description.

1. Your teacher will give your pair a short profile of a fictional person.

2. Read the profile and discuss it with your partner. Based on the information, what do you think this person is like? Make guesses using the prompts below. For example: 'I think he probably reads a lot of books.' or 'I bet she is very creative.'

Who do you think...?
• ...is very creative?
• ...works hard?
• ...is very tidy?
• ...is romantic?
• ...has a lot of secrets?
• ...likes dancing?
• ...eats healthy food?
• ...plays a musical instrument?

3. Be ready to share one or two of your guesses about your character with the class and explain why you think so.

tags.teacher_instruction: CRITICAL: The original activity involved students making guesses about each other, which is highly sensitive and can lead to negative feelings. This version has been completely changed to use fictional profiles. You must prepare 3-4 short, fictional character descriptions or use anonymous stock photos. This preserves the language goal (making inferences) while creating a safe learning environment.

title: How-To Guide: Explaining a Process
full_description:
In your future jobs, you will often need to explain how to do something. Let's practice!

1. In pairs, choose one of the processes below, or think of another one you know well.
• How to change a car tire
• How to set up a new smartphone
• How to cook a simple meal (e.g., pasta with sauce)
• How to use a specific tool from your vocational field (e.g., a drill, a wrench)
• How to connect a laptop to a projector

2. Student A will explain the process step-by-step to Student B. Use sequencing words like: *First, Next, Then, After that, Finally*.

3. Student B will listen carefully and can ask questions about any steps that are unclear. Make a note if you think your partner missed an important step.

4. Swap roles with a new process.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original list of tasks was outdated and random. This list is more practical and directly relevant to vocational students' lives. Encourage students to choose tasks related to their specific field of study (e.g., IT, construction, health, mechanics) to make the practice more meaningful. Write the sequencing words on the board for support.

title: Workplace Rules: The Dos and Don'ts
full_description:
Every workplace has official rules and unwritten rules. Let's explore them.

1. In pairs, imagine you are training a new apprentice (`lærling`) at a real or imaginary workplace related to your studies.

2. Create a list of 'Dos' (things you should do) and 'Don'ts' (things you must not do). Think about:
• Safety rules
• How to talk to the boss and colleagues
• Lunch breaks
• Using your phone
• Being on time

3. After making your list, decide on the #1 most important 'Do' and the #1 most important 'Don't'.

4. Be ready to share your most important rules with the class and explain why they are so important.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a highly relevant activity for vocational students. Frame it as direct preparation for their work placements (`utplassering`). Encourage them to think about real situations they have experienced or might experience. The final sharing session is a good opportunity to discuss workplace culture.

title: Role-Play: First Driving Lesson
full_description:
This is a role-play activity in pairs. One student is the driving instructor, and the other is the learner driver on their first lesson.

1. **Instructor:** Your job is to give clear, calm instructions. Tell the learner exactly what to do, step-by-step.

2. **Learner:** Your job is to listen carefully and follow the instructions exactly as you hear them.

3. Use the vocabulary below to help you. The instructor can start with: 'Okay, first, please adjust your seat and mirrors.'
• Vocabulary: ignition, brake, accelerator, clutch (on manual cars), gear stick, steering wheel, indicator, handbrake, seat belt, mirrors, pull out, change gear, accelerate, turn right/left.

4. After a few minutes, swap roles.

5. At the end, discuss with your partner: Was the lesson successful? Were the instructions easy to follow?

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a very relevant topic for many VG1 students. Pre-teach or review the key vocabulary on the board before they begin. You can also mention the difference between manual and automatic cars, as this affects the required vocabulary.

title: Cultural Differences: Everyday Life
full_description:
How we do everyday things can be very different from country to country. Being aware of this is a key part of global competence.

1. In small groups, discuss how the following activities might be different in Norway compared to other countries you know (from travel, movies, or online).
• Greetings and introductions
• Public transport etiquette
• Shopping and paying for things
• Rules for driving
• Tipping in cafés or restaurants

2. Share the most interesting or surprising difference your group discussed with the rest of the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: Frame this activity as a way to build cultural awareness, which is a valuable skill in any international workplace. The goal is curiosity and understanding, not judgment. Encourage students to share respectfully.

title: Pitch an Invention: The Next Big Thing
full_description:
Imagine you are entrepreneurs pitching an idea for a new, useful invention. This could be a physical product or a digital app.

1. In small groups, brainstorm a common problem that you or people you know experience. It could be a problem at school, at home, or related to your field of study.

2. Invent a product or app that solves this problem. Give it a creative name.

3. Draw a simple picture of your invention.

4. Prepare a short presentation (a 'pitch'). In your pitch, you should:
• Explain the problem your invention solves.
• Describe what your invention is and how it works.
• Explain who would want to buy it.

5. Present your pitch to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is an excellent activity for practicing persuasive language and entrepreneurship skills. Encourage creativity. You can frame it like the TV shows 'Løvens Hule' or 'Shark Tank' to make it more engaging.

title: Secret Agent Mission Briefing
full_description:
In this creative activity, you are a team of secret agents.

1. In your group, first create your supervillain. Give them a name and a silly or diabolical evil plan.

2. Next, choose five everyday objects from your school bags (e.g., a pen, a water bottle, keys, a notebook). These are now your high-tech spy gadgets!

3. For each gadget, decide on its secret function. For example: 'This pen is actually a tranquilizer dart launcher,' or 'This water bottle contains a truth serum.'

4. Write a short 'Mission Briefing' for another team of agents. Your briefing should explain:
• The villain's evil plan.
• How to use your five gadgets to stop them.

5. Present your mission and demonstrate your creative gadgets to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity requires imagination and creativity. To get them started, model an example of turning an everyday object (like a whiteboard marker) into a spy gadget. The focus is on creative language and presentation skills.

title: The Problem House: Instructions for a Friend
full_description:
1. In groups, imagine you are going on holiday. A friend is going to look after your house, but your house has some very strange problems and quirks.

2. Write a list of instructions for your friend. You need to explain the problems and what your friend needs to do. Be creative!
• Example: 'When you use the microwave, you must also turn on the radio, otherwise the garage door will open.'
• Example: 'The cat only drinks sparkling water. The plants must be watered with milk on Tuesdays.'

3. Read your funny list of instructions to the class. We will decide which group has the strangest house.

4. **Extension Activity:** In pairs, role-play a phone call. One student is the homeowner on holiday. The other is the house-sitter, who has lost the instructions and is calling because something has gone wrong.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices giving instructions and using modals (must, have to, need to) in a humorous and creative context. Encourage students to be as imaginative as possible. The role-play extension is excellent for spontaneous speaking practice.

title: What's My Workplace? Guessing Game
full_description:
Let's play a guessing game in pairs.

1. Student A secretly chooses a workplace, preferably one related to a vocational field. Then, think of a specific job within that workplace.
• Example Workplace: Construction Site
• Example Job: Electrician

2. Student B's goal is to guess the job by asking only 'yes/no' questions. First, try to find the workplace, then the specific job.

3. Here is an example conversation:
B: Do you work inside?
A: Sometimes, but mostly outside.
B: Do you work on a construction site?
A: Yes.
B: Do you work with wood?
A: No.
B: Do you work with electricity?
A: Yes.
B: Are you an electrician?
A: Yes, you got it!

4. Swap roles and play again.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write a list of relevant workplaces on the board to help students get started (e.g., car workshop, hospital, IT office, restaurant, hair salon, factory). This is a great way to practice job-related vocabulary and forming questions.

title: What's My Job? Team Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a fast-paced team game!

1. Your teacher will read a sentence that someone might say at their job.

2. The first team to shout out the correct job title wins a point for their team.

3. For example, if the teacher says: 'Are you ready to order?'
Your team should shout: 'Waiter!' or 'Waitress!'

tags.teacher_instruction: Prepare a list of 10-15 sentences corresponding to various jobs, especially those relevant to your students' vocational fields. Examples: 'Have you tried turning it off and on again?' (IT support); 'I need to check the engine oil.' (Mechanic); 'Your appointment is at 10:30.' (Receptionist).

title: Job Skills and Personal Strengths
full_description:
To be successful in a job, you need both technical skills and personal strengths.

1. As a class, let's brainstorm a list of jobs, especially jobs related to your fields of study. Your teacher will write them on the board.

2. In pairs or small groups, choose one job from the board. Discuss and make a list of the skills and personal qualities needed for that job.

3. Use some of these adjectives to help you, and add your own ideas:
• decisive, confident, motivated, creative, organised, responsible, patient, flexible, good with people, detail-oriented, hard-working.

4. Be ready to present your ideas. For example: 'To be a good healthcare worker, you need to be patient and responsible. You also need to be good with people.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent preparation for writing a CV and for job interviews. When the groups present, you can create a master list of skills and qualities on the board for everyone's reference.

title: Writing a Professional Profile for a CV
full_description:
A 'personal profile' is a short paragraph at the top of a CV. It is your first chance to impress an employer.

1. As a class, we will look at an example of a personal profile and identify its key features.

2. In pairs, review a list of useful phrases for writing a professional profile. Discuss which phrases describe you now, and which ones you want to describe you in the future.
• Example phrases: 'I am a well-organised and responsible person', 'I work well as part of a team', 'I enjoy learning new skills', 'I am committed to high-quality work'.

3. Now, it's your turn to write your own personal profile. Write 3-4 sentences that describe your strengths and ambitions related to your vocational field.

4. Share your profile with a partner and give each other positive and constructive feedback.

tags.teacher_instruction: Provide the example profile and a list of useful phrases on the board or a handout. This is a very practical skill for students preparing for work placements (`utplassering`). Emphasize a positive and confident tone.

title: Job Ad Role-Play: Applying for a Position
full_description:
This multi-part activity simulates the first step of applying for a job.

1. **Write the Ad:** In pairs, imagine your company needs a new apprentice (`lærling`). Write a short job advertisement (`stillingsannonse`). Include:
• Job title and main tasks
• Required qualifications and skills
• Personal qualities you are looking for

2. **Swap and Prepare:** Swap your job ad with another pair. Read the ad you received and prepare some questions to ask about the job.

3. **Role-Play the Call:** Now, role-play a phone call with the pair who wrote the ad.
• **Applicant:** Call to ask your questions about the job.
• **Company Rep:** Answer the applicant's questions.

4. Switch roles so everyone gets to practice being both the applicant and the company representative.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a great follow-up to activities about job skills and CV writing. Encourage students to ask realistic questions about things like working hours, pay, company culture, and specific tasks.

title: Show and Tell: My Favourite Gadget or Tool
full_description:
For our next lesson, your homework is to bring a gadget or a tool that you use often. If you can't bring the object, a picture of it is fine.

In class, you will work in pairs for a 'Show and Tell'.

1. Show your gadget or tool to your partner.

2. Explain what it is and what it is used for.

3. Describe its main features and explain why you like it or find it useful.

4. Demonstrate how it works, if possible.

tags.teacher_instruction: Announce this homework in the lesson before you plan to do the activity. Reassure students that the 'gadget' or 'tool' can be simple, like their phone, headphones, a gaming controller, or a specific tool from their vocational field. The goal is confident speaking and clear explanation.

title: What Do They Need? Brainstorming Essentials
full_description:
Let's practice thinking about other people's needs and perspectives.

1. In small groups, discuss what the following people or characters probably need most in their situation. For each one, agree on the top three most important things.
• A student during exam week
• A professional esports gamer
• A person starting a new business
• Your favorite hero (or villain) from a movie or TV show

2. Use language of speculation, for example: 'A student probably needs...', 'They might need...', 'It's essential for them to have...'

3. Be ready to share your group's best ideas with the class and explain your choices.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices modals of speculation and vocabulary related to needs. The list of people has been updated to be more relevant and engaging for teenagers. Encourage creative thinking, especially for the fictional character.

title: Modern Survival Kit: Top 10 Essentials
full_description:
Imagine you have to pack a 'survival kit' for one month in modern society. You can only choose 10 items to have with you.

1. In pairs, first brainstorm a big list of items you think are essential for your daily life.

2. From your big list, you must negotiate and agree on a final list of only 10 items.

3. Now, rank your final list of 10 items in order of importance, from #1 (most important) to #10 (least important).

4. Join another pair and compare your lists. Be ready to defend your choices! Why is a smartphone more important than a toothbrush? Or is it?

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a classic decision-making and negotiation activity. It sparks great debate and practices the language of justification ('We chose this because...', 'This is more important than...'). Clarify that this is about surviving in 'modern society', not on a desert island.

title: Improve Our Community
full_description:
In this activity, you will work in groups to brainstorm solutions to real-world issues.

1. As a group, choose one of the following topics to focus on:
• How can we make our local town/area a better place for young people?
• What is one practical idea to make our school more environmentally friendly?
• How can we create a more positive and respectful online community (e.g., on social media or in gaming)?

2. Brainstorm at least five specific, practical ideas for your chosen topic. For example, for the first topic: 'We could create a dedicated outdoor hangout spot with free Wi-Fi and charging stations.'

3. Choose your group's best idea and prepare to share it with the class. Explain what the idea is and why you think it would work.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity encourages critical thinking and problem-solving in English. The topics have been made more specific and relevant to students' lives. Frame it as a way to practice participating in important societal conversations.

title: My Future Career: Skills and Requirements
full_description:
Let's talk about the future and what it takes to succeed in a job.

1. Think about your future career. This can be the job you are training for, or another dream job.

2. In pairs, take turns describing your chosen job to your partner. Then, discuss what a person needs to be successful in that role. Talk about:
• **Skills:** What do you need to be *able to do*? (e.g., 'You need to be able to communicate clearly.')
• **Knowledge:** What do you need to *know*? (e.g., 'You need to know specific software.')
• **Personal Qualities:** What kind of *person* do you need to be? (e.g., 'You need to be creative.')

3. Listen to your partner and ask them follow-up questions about the job they describe.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity makes job-related language personal and forward-looking. It's excellent practice for job interviews, where candidates are often asked to reflect on the requirements of the role and their own suitability.

title: Invention and Necessity
full_description:
There is a famous English saying: 'Necessity is the mother of invention.' This means that new things are often created because there is a real need or problem to solve.

1. In small groups, brainstorm a list of 5 important modern inventions that you use in your daily life (e.g., smartphones, GPS, online streaming, wireless headphones).

2. For each invention on your list, discuss and write down the 'necessity' that you think led to its creation. What problem did it solve for people?
• **Example:**
• **Invention:** The remote control.
• **Necessity:** People needed a way to change TV channels without getting up from the sofa.

3. Share one of your group's examples with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a good critical thinking exercise that encourages students to think about the 'why' behind technology. Start by modeling a clear example on the board to make sure they understand the concept of 'necessity'.

title: Then and Now: A Daily Life Comparison
full_description:
How has daily life changed over the generations? Let's compare life today with life in the past.

1. In small groups, choose one of the following time periods to discuss:
• When your grandparents were teenagers (e.g., the 1960s/70s)
• Norway in the 1990s

2. Discuss what daily life was like then. Think about what people *had to do*, *used to do*, or *couldn't do* regarding technology, school, and social life.

3. Use comparative language and phrases for talking about the past.
• Example: 'In the 90s, people used to listen to music on a Walkman, but now we stream everything on our phones.'
• Example: 'Our grandparents had to write letters. They couldn't send a Snap.'

4. Be ready to share one or two interesting comparisons with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is an excellent activity for practicing 'used to' and past modals in a meaningful context. The time periods are more concrete and relatable for students than the original '500 years ago'. This often leads to interesting discussions about technological and social change.

title: Household Tasks Chain Game
full_description:
Let's play a fast-paced chain game in groups of three. The topic is tasks around the house.

Here is how it works:
1. **Student A** starts by naming a household chore. (e.g., 'We have to clean the bathroom.')
2. **Student B** responds by saying what you need to do it. (e.g., 'We need rubber gloves and cleaning spray.')
3. **Student C** then names a new chore. (e.g., 'Okay, now we have to cook dinner.')
4. The chain continues with Student A saying what is needed for that task, and so on.

Try to keep the chain going for at least two minutes!

tags.teacher_instruction: Model one or two rounds of the game with a group so everyone understands the flow. This is a fun, low-pressure drill for practicing the structure 'We need...' and vocabulary for household items. The original 'needs + -ing' variation was removed to simplify the main task for B1 level.

title: Rules for a New Flatmate
full_description:
Living with other people requires clear communication and rules.

1. In pairs, imagine you share a flat (`leilighet`) and you are getting a new flatmate (`romkamerat`). To avoid future problems, you must agree on a set of house rules.

2. Discuss and create a list of rules for your new flatmate. You and your partner must agree on each rule. Consider these topics:
• Cleaning schedule
• Guests and parties
• Noise levels (music, TV, etc.)
• Shared food in the fridge
• Paying bills on time

3. Use modal verbs like *must, have to, should, can't, mustn't*.
For example: 'You must pay your share of the rent by the 1st of the month.'

4. Present your top three most important rules to the class and explain why they are necessary.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is great practice for negotiation and using modals of obligation and permission. It's a very practical and relevant scenario for young adults. Encourage a respectful discussion tone.

title: Guess the Place from the Rules
full_description:
Let's play a guessing game in small groups.

1. One person secretly thinks of a specific place (e.g., a library, a cinema, an airport, a swimming pool).

2. They give the group one rule for that place, using modals like 'You must...', 'You mustn't...', or 'You have to...'.
• Example clue: 'You mustn't talk on your phone.'

3. The other students in the group try to guess the place.
• Example guess: 'Are you in a cinema?'

4. If the guess is wrong, the person gives another clue.
• Example clue: 'No. You have to be very quiet.'... Guess: 'Are you in a library?'... 'Yes!'

5. Take turns being the clue-giver.

tags.teacher_instruction: Model a round for the whole class to ensure everyone understands the game. This is a fun and engaging way to practice modals of obligation and prohibition. You can list some possible places on the board to give students ideas.

title: Our Classroom Code of Conduct
full_description:
As a class, we need to agree on some rules for a positive and productive learning environment.

1. In small groups, discuss and write down ideas for our classroom 'code of conduct'.

2. Use these three headings for your ideas:
• We agree to... (e.g., ...help each other.)
• We should avoid... (e.g., ...using our phones during instruction.)
• We don't have to... (e.g., ...always agree with each other.)

3. After your group discussion, we will share ideas as a class and create one final Code of Conduct together.

tags.teacher_instruction: Frame this as a collaborative task to create a shared 'kontrakt' or agreement. The goal is to foster a sense of ownership and responsibility for the classroom environment, rather than imposing top-down rules.

title: Workplace Safety Briefing
full_description:
In any vocational field, health and safety are extremely important. In this task, you will create a safety briefing for a specific workplace.

1. Your teacher will assign a workplace situation to your group (e.g., a professional kitchen, a car workshop, a construction site, a healthcare setting).

2. In your group, brainstorm a list of safety rules for that workplace. Organize your ideas under these four headings:
• Must (e.g., 'You must wear safety glasses.')
• Must not (e.g., 'You must not use a machine without training.')
• Should (e.g., 'You should always report accidents.')
• Don't have to (e.g., 'You don't have to ask for permission to take a short break.')

3. Prepare to present your most important safety rules to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a very practical and relevant activity. Assign workplace situations that align with your students' vocational streams. The use of modals (must, should) is the key language focus here.

title: Creative Excuses & Childhood Rules
full_description:
Part 1: Making Excuses
Imagine you arrive one hour late for an important meeting with your boss. In pairs, think of three creative and detailed excuses. You must use past obligations in your excuse.
• Example: 'I'm so sorry I'm late. My car broke down and I had to wait for the tow truck.'

Part 2: Childhood Rules
In small groups, discuss the rules you had when you were a child. Use the questions below to start your conversation.
• What did you have to do? (e.g., homework, chores)
• What were you allowed to do? (e.g., screen time, staying out late)
• What couldn't you do?

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices past modals of obligation (`had to`, `was/were allowed to`). For Part 1, encourage funny and imaginative excuses. For Part 2, keep the discussion light and focused on general cultural norms for children rather than sensitive family details.

title: Perfect Modals: Regrets and Excuses
full_description:
We often use special phrases to talk about things we planned to do but didn't.

1. First, let's look at these structures:
• 'I should have...' (used for regrets)
• 'I was supposed to...' (used for unfulfilled plans)

2. Make a private list of three things you have failed to do recently. For example: finish a school project, clean your room, call a relative.

3. In pairs, share your lists. Your partner will challenge you, and you must provide an excuse.
• A: 'You should have cleaned your room.'
• B: 'I know, but I had too much homework.'
• A: 'You were supposed to call your grandparents.'
• B: 'Yes, but I couldn't find my phone.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a focused grammar practice activity for perfect modals. Write the target structures `I should have...` and `I was supposed to...` on the board. The goal is accurate production in a communicative context. Remind students they don't have to share anything too personal.

title: Listening Skills: Who, Where, What?
full_description:
Listen carefully to the short situations your teacher will read.

1. For each of the 10 situations, listen and write down your answers to these three questions in your notebook:
• Is it an offer or a request?
• Where is it happening?
• Who is speaking to whom?

2. I will read each situation twice. The first time, just listen. The second time, write your notes.

3. After we have heard all the situations, compare your notes with a partner.

4. Finally, we will check the answers together as a class.

tags.teacher_instruction: You will need to prepare a list of 10 short, modern situations before class. The goal is for students to infer context from tone and vocabulary. Examples: 'I'll have a latte with oat milk, please.' (Customer to barista in a café); 'Would you mind turning your music down? I'm trying to study.' (Flatmate to flatmate); 'Shall I help you carry that?' (Stranger to someone struggling with bags).

title: Making Offers and Requests
full_description:
Part 1: Making Requests
1. Use the prompts below to make polite requests. Use phrases like 'Can I...?', 'Could I...?', or 'Do you mind if I...?'.
• Prompt: It's hot in here. -> Request: 'Could I open a window?'
• Prompts: I'm thirsty. / I don't understand this task. / My phone battery is dead. / I forgot my wallet.

Part 2: Making Offers
1. Now, work in pairs. Student A says the prompt. Student B makes a polite offer using phrases like 'I'll...', 'Shall I...?', or 'Do you want me to...?'.
• A: 'It's hot in here.'
• B: 'Shall I open a window for you?'
• Use the same prompts as in Part 1.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the key phrases for requests and offers on the board. This is a fluency-focused activity designed to practice functional language in a structured way.

title: Role-Play: Checking into a Hotel
full_description:
In this activity, you will role-play checking into a hotel.

1. Work in pairs. One student is the 'Guest', the other is the 'Receptionist'.

2. Act out the conversation. The Guest has just arrived and wants to check in. The Receptionist should welcome them and handle the check-in process.

3. Try to use some of the vocabulary below in your conversation.
• Vocabulary: single/double room, booking/reservation, en suite bathroom, check-in/check-out, key card, Wi-Fi password, breakfast time, room service.

4. After you have finished your role-play, swap roles and try again.

title: The Nightmare House-Sitter
full_description:
This is a creative writing activity in two parts.

1. **The Request Note:** In pairs, imagine you are going on a ten-day holiday. You have asked a friend to house-sit for you. Write a note asking them to take care of a few things while you're away. Mention these things in your note:
• your cat, your plants, a hole in the roof, an ant problem, your noisy neighbours, and paying a bill.

2. **The Reply Note:** Swap your note with another pair. Now, imagine you are the house-sitter, and everything has gone completely wrong! Write a reply note to the homeowners telling them about the disasters. You can start your note like this:

'Dear ___,
This has been the worst week of my life...'

tags.teacher_instruction: Frame this as a humorous writing task. Encourage creativity and exaggeration in the second part (the reply from the house-sitter) to make it funnier. This is great practice for narrative writing and using past tenses.

title: Formal vs. Informal Language
full_description:
The way we speak and write changes depending on the situation. This is called 'register'.

1. **Sorting:** In groups, copy the table below. Write these phrases in the correct section of the table:
• Could I...? / Can you...? / Would you mind...? / I'll... / Give me... / Do you want...? / Would you like...? / Do you mind if I...?

| | Request | Offer |
|---|---|---|
| Formal | | |
| Informal | | |

2. **Ordering:** In pairs, put these requests in order from most formal to most informal.
• Shut up!
• Could you please be quiet?
• I'm terribly sorry, but would you mind being a little less noisy?
• Quiet, please.

3. **Transforming:** In pairs, make these informal expressions more formal.
• 'Hi.' -> 'Hello.' or 'Good morning.'
• 'Want a hand?'
• 'Leave me alone!'

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity teaches an important sociolinguistic skill. Start by explaining the concept of register (formal vs. informal) and give examples of situations for each (e.g., job interview vs. talking with friends).

title: Understanding Tone and Register
full_description:
1. **Dictation:** Divide your page into two columns: 'Formal' and 'Informal'. Your teacher will read several sentences. Listen and write each sentence in the correct column.

2. **Dialogue 1:** Listen to this informal dialogue. Write it down in your 'Informal' column.
• A: Hey, you!
• B: What?
• A: Pass me that wrench.
• B: Sure. Here you go.

3. **Rewrite Dialogue 1:** In pairs, rewrite the informal dialogue in your 'Formal' column. How can you make it more polite?

4. **Dialogue 2:** Now, do the same for this dialogue.
• A: Want a hand with that?
• B: Oh, yeah, thanks. Can you hold this?
• A: No problem.

tags.teacher_instruction: When reading the dictation sentences and dialogues, use an appropriate tone of voice to help students infer the context. This activity is a great practical application of the concept of register.

title: Role-Play: The Polite Refusal
full_description:
This role-play is about asking for permission and politely refusing.

1. Work in pairs. Student A, you are a guest in Student B's house. You are very curious!

2. Student A: Ask for permission to do things or use items in the house. Use 'May I...?' or 'Can I...?'.

3. Student B: You are protective of your things. You must refuse Student A's requests, but do it as politely as possible. Give a reason for your refusal.

Example:
A: 'Can I play your guitar?'
B: 'I'd rather you didn't. It's very old and fragile.'

Talk about: the TV, the computer, the photo album, the kitchen, the CD collection.

tags.teacher_instruction: Pre-teach phrases for polite refusal, such as: 'I'd rather you didn't...', 'I'm sorry, but...', or 'Actually, I'd prefer if you didn't because...'. The goal is to practice being assertive while maintaining politeness.

title: Laws and Age Limits: A Global Comparison
full_description:
The age at which you are legally allowed to do certain things varies from country to country.

1. In small groups, discuss the legal age for the following activities in Norway.

2. Then, discuss if you know the legal age for these activities in other countries (like the USA, Sweden, the UK, or any other country you know about).

• At what age can you...?
• Get a driver's license for a car?
• Vote in a national election?
• Buy energy drinks?
• Get a tattoo?

3. As a class, we will share what we found. Are there any big surprises?

tags.teacher_instruction: This topic is marked as sensitive because discussions about legal ages can sometimes lead to debates about alcohol or other controlled substances. Frame the activity as a factual comparison of laws, not a debate on their merits. Keep the topics focused on the provided list (driving, voting, etc.) to maintain a safe and productive discussion.

title: Smartphones: Pros, Cons, and Costs
full_description:
Part 1: Pros and Cons
In small groups, discuss the advantages and disadvantages of smartphones in our daily lives. Create a list with two columns: 'Pros' and 'Cons'. Try to think of at least three points for each column.

Part 2: The Best Deal
In the same groups, discuss your smartphone plans. You don't need to talk about exact prices if you don't want to. Instead, compare the features.
• Who has the most data?
• Who has the fastest speed?
• Are there any special benefits included?
• Overall, who do you think has the best value plan?

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, you can create a master Pros/Cons list on the board from student suggestions. For Part 2, the focus is on comparative language ('more data than...', 'faster than...', 'the best value because...').

title: Leaving a Clear Voicemail
full_description:
Imagine you need to leave a message on someone's voicemail. It is important to be clear and include all the necessary information.

1. Your teacher will give your group a situation. For example: 'Call to confirm an appointment for a work placement.'

2. In your group, write down the voicemail message you would leave. Make up any necessary details like names, dates, and times.

3. One person from your group will 'perform' the voicemail for the class. The rest of the class must listen carefully and take notes on the key information:
• Who called?
• What was the reason for the call?
• What is the callback number or what should the person do next?

4. We will check if the listeners understood the message correctly.

tags.teacher_instruction: Before they start, review the key parts of a good voicemail: name, reason for call, key details, and a clear callback number. Prepare a few modern situations on slips of paper (e.g., calling a potential employer, rescheduling an appointment, ordering a takeaway).

title: Professional Voicemail Greetings
full_description:
The outgoing message on a business's voicemail needs to be professional and helpful.

1. In small groups, choose one of the following places:
• A car workshop
• A hair salon
• A local restaurant
• An IT support company

2. Compose and write down the professional voicemail greeting for that business. Your message must include:
• The name of the business.
• Information about opening hours.
• An option for what to do in an emergency or where to find more information (e.g., a website).

3. Be prepared to read your professional greeting to the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: Discuss the difference between a personal voicemail greeting ('Hi, you've reached Jo, leave a message!') and a professional one. The key elements are clarity, essential information, and a professional tone.

title: Decoding Digital Slang
full_description:
Language changes quickly, especially online! Let's look at some common digital slang.

1. In pairs, translate these short messages and abbreviations into full, correct English sentences.
• btw, call me later
• idk what the homework is
• ty for the help!
• brb, getting a snack
• lol that's so funny

2. Now, using similar abbreviations and slang, write a short text message conversation between two friends who are arranging to meet up.

3. Swap your conversation with another pair. Your job is to translate their slang conversation back into full English sentences.

tags.teacher_instruction: The original slang was very outdated. This version uses abbreviations that are still common. This is a fun way to discuss register and the evolution of language, while also practicing formal sentence construction during the 'translation' phase.

title: Online Research Project: Plan an Activity
full_description:
This is a project that requires you to find and compare information online.

1. Choose one of the following research tasks:
• **Task A: Find the Best Smartphone Plan.** Research and compare two different mobile data plans available in Norway. Find information about price, data amount, and any special features. Decide which one is the best value.
• **Task B: Plan a Class Trip.** Visit the website for a local cinema, bowling alley, or other event venue. Find out what's on, check ticket prices, and find the opening times. Propose a specific activity for a class trip.

2. Work individually or in small groups to gather the information.

3. Prepare a short presentation to share your findings and your recommendation with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity requires access to computers and the internet. The goal is to practice practical research skills, information synthesis, and presentation. You could suggest Norwegian price comparison sites (like prisjakt.no) or local venue websites (like sfkino.no) to help them start.

title: Adjectives and Adverbs Transformation
full_description:
We can often say the same thing in two different ways, using either an adjective or an adverb.

1. In pairs, listen to the sentences your teacher reads. Write them down.

2. For each sentence, rewrite it to change the structure from 'adjective + noun' to 'verb + adverb'.
• Example: 'Henry is a dangerous driver.' -> 'Henry drives dangerously.'

Sentences:
• Tim is a heavy smoker.
• Kathy is a beautiful dancer.
• Ken is an excellent writer.
• Rebecca is a quick worker.
• Lucy is a nice singer.

3. In small groups, use adverbs to talk about your own skills. For example: 'I sing badly,' or 'I drive carefully.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a grammar-focused activity. Write the two patterns on the board: `a/an + (adjective) + (noun)` and `(verb) + (adverb)`. Complete the first example with the whole class to ensure they understand the transformation.

title: Adverb Mime Challenge
full_description:
Let's play a fun acting game to practice adverbs!

1. Your teacher will mime an action (e.g., making a sandwich). The class guesses the action.

2. Now, in pairs, one student will secretly choose an adverb from the list below.

3. That student will mime one of the actions from the board, but they must act it out *in the manner of their secret adverb*.

4. Their partner tries to guess the adverb. For example: 'You are making a sandwich nervously.'

5. Swap roles and try again.
• Adverbs: sadly, gently, shyly, heroically, impatiently, nervously, confidently, happily, angrily, slowly, quickly, carefully, clumsily.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a high-energy, kinesthetic activity. Model one round yourself by miming an action (e.g., opening a door) in a specific way (e.g., slowly) and having the class guess the adverb. Encourage exaggerated acting to make the adverb clear.

title: Expressing Needs and Wants
full_description:
Part 1: Quick-Fire Drill
Your teacher will say a statement. Repeat the statement, but add something that you need.
• Teacher: 'I'm hungry.' -> Student: 'I'm hungry and I need some food.'
• Teacher: 'This project is stressful.' -> Student: 'This project is stressful and I need a break.'

Part 2: What Do People Need?
In small groups, decide what the following people need. For each one, name the three most important things.
• A tourist visiting Norway for the first time
• A professional athlete before a big competition
• A new-born baby
• A student preparing for an exam

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices the verb 'need' in different contexts. The first part is a fast-paced oral drill. For the second part, encourage students to explain *why* something is needed, which promotes deeper discussion and more complex language use.

title: Needs vs. Wants: A Survival Debate
full_description:
1. In pairs, brainstorm a list of 20 items you think are essential for your daily life in modern society.

2. Look at your list and discuss: which of these are true 'needs' (you can't live well without them) and which are 'wants' (they make life better, but aren't essential)?

3. As a pair, negotiate and create a final, ranked list of the top 5 'bare minimum' things a person needs to survive comfortably today. Be prepared to defend your choices.

4. As a class, we will compare lists and debate which items are the most essential.

title: One Idea to Improve Our Community
full_description:
1. In small groups, choose ONE of these topics to focus on:
• How can we improve our local town/area for young people?
• What is one practical idea to make our school more environmentally friendly?
• How could we use technology to solve a local problem?

2. Brainstorm at least five specific, practical ideas for your chosen topic.

3. Choose your single best idea as a group.

4. Prepare to present your idea to the class. Explain the problem and how your idea would help solve it.

tags.teacher_instruction: Frame this as a practical problem-solving task, not a philosophical debate. The goal is to generate concrete, actionable ideas using persuasive language.

title: The Future of Work: Invent a Job
full_description:
1. In small groups, brainstorm a list of jobs that exist today but didn't exist 20 years ago (e.g., social media manager, drone pilot, app developer).

2. For each job, discuss the skills and abilities needed. For example: 'A drone pilot needs to have good hand-eye coordination.'

3. Now, think about the future. Invent one new job that you think might exist in the year 2040. Give it a name and describe what the person does and what skills they need.

4. Share your new job idea with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity encourages creative and critical thinking about the future of work, which is very relevant for vocational students.

title: The Problem-Solving Power of Inventions
full_description:
The saying 'Necessity is the mother of invention' means that people invent things because they have a problem that needs solving.

1. In small groups, brainstorm a list of five important inventions from history (e.g., the printing press, the refrigerator, the internet).

2. For each invention, discuss and write down the 'necessity' or problem that it solved. For example: 'The refrigerator was invented because people needed a way to keep food fresh for longer.'

3. Share your group's most interesting example with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a good warm-up for a larger discussion on technology or history. Encourage students to think about the cause-and-effect relationship between problems and solutions.

title: Then vs. Now: A Generational Comparison
full_description:
1. In small groups, think about the time when your parents or grandparents were teenagers.

2. Discuss the following questions about their generation:
• What did they **have to do** that we don't have to do now? (e.g., 'They had to use a payphone to call friends.')
• What did they **used to do** for fun? (e.g., 'They used to listen to music on vinyl records.')
• What **couldn't they do** that we can do now? (e.g., 'They couldn't order food with an app.')

3. Make a few notes on the biggest differences between their teenage life and yours.

4. Share one interesting comparison with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity is excellent for practicing 'used to', past modals (`had to`, `couldn't`), and comparative structures in a meaningful context. It can encourage students to talk with their families about the past.

title: Household Chores: What Do We Need?
full_description:
Let's play a fast-paced chain game in groups of three (Student A, B, and C).

1.  **Student A** starts by naming a household chore. (e.g., 'We have to bake a cake.')
2.  **Student B** responds by saying what you need to do it. (e.g., 'We need flour, eggs, and a mixer.')
3.  **Student C** then names a new chore. (e.g., 'Okay, now the floor needs cleaning.')
4.  The chain continues with Student A saying what is needed for that task, and so on.

Try to keep the chain going without long pauses!

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a fun oral fluency drill. Model one round with a group. For a B2 level challenge, encourage students to use the structure 'The [noun] needs [verb]-ing' (e.g., 'The car needs washing,' 'The lawn needs mowing').

title: Creating the Perfect Shared Flat: House Rules Pitch
full_description:
1. In pairs, imagine you are starting a shared flat (`kollektiv`) and are looking for a new flatmate. You need to create a clear set of house rules to ensure everyone can live together happily.

2. Agree on a list of rules covering these topics:
    • Cleaning responsibilities
    • Guests and parties
    • Noise levels
    • Common areas (kitchen, living room)
    • Shared expenses

3. Now, prepare a short 'pitch' for the class. Your goal is to persuade the other students that your flat would be the best one to live in because your rules are fair and create a great atmosphere.

4. After all the pitches, the class will vote on which shared flat they would most like to join.

tags.teacher_instruction: The focus here is on persuasive language ('Our rules are best because...', 'This creates a respectful environment by...'). Encourage pairs to think about the *benefits* of their rules.

title: Match the Rule to the Place
full_description:
1. In groups, you will get a list of rules and a list of places.
2. Your task is to match each rule to the correct place.
3. Discuss your choices in your group and be ready to explain your reasoning. Why does this rule belong to that place?

**Rules:**
• You must not talk during the performance.
• You have to show your passport.
• You must return your books on time.
• You should warm up before exercising.
• You mustn't run by the poolside.

**Places:**
• Airport security
• Library
• Swimming pool
• Theatre
• Gym

tags.teacher_instruction: Prepare the lists on the board or a handout. This version is a logical deduction and discussion task that focuses on understanding the meaning of different modals (must, should, have to).

title: A Better School: Proposing New Rules
full_description:
1. In small groups, imagine you are a student council with the power to change the school rules (`ordensreglement`).
2. Your task is to propose ONE new rule that you think would make the school better.
3. You must also propose ONE old rule that you think should be removed.
4. Prepare to present your proposals to the class. You must explain *why* your new rule is a good idea and *why* the old rule should be removed. Use phrases like:
    • 'We think we should have a rule that...'
    • 'This would improve...'
    • 'We believe we shouldn't have to...'
    • 'This rule is outdated because...'

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices persuasive language and critical thinking. It empowers students by allowing them to constructively critique and suggest changes. Ensure the discussion remains respectful.

title: Workplace Safety Scenarios
full_description:
1. In groups, your teacher will give you a workplace scenario related to a vocational field (e.g., working in a commercial kitchen, on a building site, in an IT server room, or in a healthcare clinic).
2. Your task is to create a Health and Safety (HMS - Helse, Miljø, og Sikkerhet) poster for that workplace.
3. On your poster, list the most important rules under four headings:
    • **MUST** (Absolutely required)
    • **MUST NOT** (Absolutely forbidden)
    • **SHOULD** (Strongly recommended)
    • **DON'T HAVE TO** (Not required)
4. Swap your finished poster with another group. Read their poster and suggest one more important rule they might have missed.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a very practical task. Prepare relevant scenarios for your students' fields. Emphasize the difference in strength between `must` and `should`. This connects directly to Norwegian HMS requirements.

title: Life in the Past: Obligations and Permissions
full_description:
1.  In small groups, discuss what life was like for teenagers in the past (e.g., when your parents were young).

2.  Use these questions to guide your conversation. Try to use the bolded language.
    • What things **did they have to** do at school or at home? (e.g., 'They **had to** share a phone with the whole family.')
    • What things **were they allowed to** do?
    • What things **couldn't they** do that you can?

3.  Think about topics like:
    • homework and studying
    • communication (phones, letters)
    • music and entertainment
    • part-time jobs

4.  Be ready to share one interesting difference your group discussed.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices past modals of obligation and permission. Focus on the structures `had to`, `was/were allowed to`, and `couldn't`. This can lead to interesting cross-generational discussions. The "excuses" part from the original was removed to focus the activity.

title: Talking About Unfinished Tasks
full_description:
Let's practice talking about things we planned to do but didn't.

1.  First, look at these two useful phrases:
    • **I should have...** (Used for something you regret not doing).
    • **I was supposed to...** (Used for a plan you didn't complete).

2.  On a piece of paper, write down a list of three things you have failed to do recently (e.g., *call a friend, finish an assignment, clean my room*).

3.  Work in pairs. Swap lists. Take turns challenging your partner and listening to their excuse.
    • Student A: 'It says here you didn't finish your assignment. You **should have** done it yesterday.'
    • Student B: 'I know, but I had too much homework.'
    • Student A: 'And you **were supposed to** call your friend.'
    • Student B: 'Yes, but my phone battery died.'

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the target phrases and examples on the board. This activity provides structured practice for advanced grammar points in a communicative context. Remind students to keep their examples school-appropriate and not too personal.

title: Listening for Context: Offers and Requests
full_description:
Part 1: Listening Task
1.  Your teacher will read 5 short dialogues. For each one, listen carefully and write down:
    a) If the main point is an OFFER or a REQUEST.
    b) Where the conversation is probably happening.
    c) The relationship between the speakers (e.g., friends, customer/employee).
2.  After listening, compare your notes with a partner.

Part 2: Personalization
1.  Think of the last request you made to someone and the last offer you made to someone.
2.  Write them down. For example:
    • Request: I asked my friend to help me with my homework.
    • Offer: I offered to buy my sister a coffee.
3.  Share your sentences with your partner.

tags.teacher_instruction: You need to prepare 5 short, clear dialogues before class. Make them modern and relevant. For example: 1) A customer ordering food via an app for pickup. 2) Someone asking a colleague for help with software. 3) A friend offering another friend a ride. This activity practices inference skills.

title: Practicing Offers and Requests
full_description:
This is a quick-fire practice activity to improve your fluency.

**Part 1: Making Requests**
Use the prompts to make polite requests. Use phrases like 'Can I...?', 'Could I...?', or 'Do you mind if I...?'.
•   **Prompt:** I'm cold.
•   **Request:** 'Do you mind if I close the window?'

**Part 2: Making Offers (in pairs)**
Student A states the problem (the prompt). Student B makes a helpful offer. Use phrases like 'I'll...', 'Shall I...?', or 'Do you want me to...?'.
•   **Student A:** 'I'm cold.'
•   **Student B:** 'Shall I close the window for you?'

**Prompts to use:**
• I'm thirsty.
• I don't understand.
• My phone is dead.
• I feel sick.
• I can't reach the top shelf.

tags.teacher_instruction: Write the key phrases for requests and offers on the board. Model one or two examples clearly. The goal is quick, confident responses.

title: Role-Play: Hotel Check-in
full_description:
This is a role-play in pairs. One of you is a 'Guest' checking into a hotel, and the other is the 'Receptionist'.

1.  **The Scenario:** The Guest has a reservation for a double room for two nights, made online.

2.  **Your Task:** Act out the check-in conversation from start to finish. The Receptionist should welcome the guest, confirm the booking, and provide key information. The Guest can ask questions.

3.  **Key Vocabulary:** Try to use some of these words and phrases in your conversation.
    • reservation / booking
    • check in / check out
    • single / double room
    • key card
    • Wi-Fi password
    • breakfast times
    • Can I have an extra pillow?
    • Where is the lift/elevator?

4.  After your role-play, swap roles with your partner.

tags.teacher_instruction: Pre-teach or review the key vocabulary. You can make it more challenging by giving the receptionist a problem to solve (e.g., 'I'm sorry, our system shows a booking for a single room. Let me fix that for you.').

title: A Favour Gone Wrong: The Phone Call
full_description:
This is a role-play activity in pairs.

**Scenario:**
Student A is on holiday. Student B agreed to house-sit for Student A as a favour. But now, there are problems!
• Problems: The cat is missing, the plants are dying, and there's a strange noise coming from the basement.

**Your Task:**
1.  **Student B (The House-Sitter):** You need to call Student A on holiday to explain the problems and ask what to do. Try not to panic!
2.  **Student A (The Homeowner):** You are trying to relax on a beach. You receive a stressful call from your house-sitter. Try to give clear instructions and calm them down.

Act out the phone call.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is an excellent activity for practicing problem-solving language, giving instructions, and expressing emotions like stress and reassurance. Encourage students to be a bit dramatic and have fun with it.

title: From Casual to Formal: Upgrading Your Language
full_description:
The language you use with friends is often different from the language you use in a professional setting. Let's practice making informal language more formal.

In pairs, rewrite these informal sentences to make them sound more formal and polite. Think about what you would say or write in a school or work environment.

1.  **Informal:** Want a hand?
    **Formal:** Would you like some help? / Can I help you with that?

2.  **Informal:** Give me that file.
    **Formal:** ?

3.  **Informal:** What's up?
    **Formal:** ?

4.  **Informal:** I'm gonna be late.
    **Formal:** ?

5.  **Informal:** Leave me alone!
    **Formal:** ?

tags.teacher_instruction: Go through the answers as a class, discussing the different possible formal variations. This is a crucial skill for workplace communication.

title: Dialogue Transformation: From Informal to Formal
full_description:
Listen to this informal dialogue your teacher reads. Write it down.

**Informal Dialogue:**
A: Yo, can I borrow your charger?
B: Dunno, mine's almost dead.
A: C'mon, just for five minutes. I'm on 1%.
B: Fine, but be quick.

Now, work in pairs. Your task is to rewrite this entire conversation to make it formal and polite. Imagine it's a conversation between two colleagues in an office.

**Formal Dialogue:**
A: ?
B: ?
... and so on.

tags.teacher_instruction: First, read the informal dialogue clearly. Then, give pairs time to work on their formal version. Finally, have a few pairs read their formal dialogues aloud. Discuss the different choices they made.

title: The Art of Persuasion: Getting to 'Yes'
full_description:
This is a negotiation role-play in pairs.

**Scenario:**
Student A wants to borrow something important from Student B (e.g., their new car for the evening, their expensive laptop for a project, their favourite jacket for a party).

**Your Task:**
1.  **Student A:** Your goal is to persuade Student B to say 'yes'. You must be very polite and convincing. Make offers to reassure them.
    • Example: 'May I please borrow your laptop? I promise I'll be extremely careful. I can leave my phone with you as a security deposit!'

2.  **Student B:** Your first instinct is to say 'no'. Listen to Student A's arguments. You can refuse, or you can be persuaded to agree, perhaps with some conditions.
    • Example: 'I don't know... it's very expensive. Okay, you can borrow it, but you must not eat or drink near it.'

Act out the conversation.

tags.teacher_instruction: This activity practices the language of persuasion, negotiation, and setting conditions. It's more advanced than simply refusing. Encourage students to think about what makes an argument convincing.

title: Permissions at School and Work
full_description:
What are you allowed to do in different situations? Let's discuss permissions.

In small groups, discuss and answer the following questions. Use phrases like 'We are allowed to...', 'We aren't allowed to...', or 'We can/can't...'.

1.  **In this school:**
    • Are you allowed to use your phone in class?
    • Are you allowed to eat or drink in the classroom?
    • Are you allowed to listen to music while you work on individual tasks?

2.  **At a typical work placement (`utplassering`):**
    • Do you think you are allowed to check social media during work hours?
    • Are you allowed to leave the workplace for lunch?
    • Are you allowed to make personal phone calls?

Discuss your answers and see if everyone in your group agrees.

tags.teacher_instruction: This revised activity practices the language (`be allowed to`) in a safe, relevant, and non-controversial context for VG1 students. It connects directly to their daily lives and future work experiences.

title: Smartphones: Pros, Cons, and Plans
full_description:
Part 1: Pros and Cons
In small groups, discuss the advantages and disadvantages of smartphones in our daily lives. Create a list with two columns: 'Pros' and 'Cons'. Try to think of at least three points for each column.

Part 2: The Best Deal
In the same groups, discuss your smartphone plans. You don't need to talk about exact prices. Instead, compare the features.
• Who has the most data (GB)?
• Who has any special benefits included (e.g., free music streaming)?
• Overall, who do you think has the best value plan and why?

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, you can create a master Pros/Cons list on the board from student suggestions. For Part 2, the focus is on comparative language ('more data than...', 'the best value because...'). Remind students they do not need to share sensitive personal information like how much they pay.

title: Leaving a Clear Voicemail Message
full_description:
Imagine you need to leave a message on someone's voicemail. It is important to be clear and include all the necessary information.

1. Your teacher will give your group a situation. For example: 'Call a company to ask about a work placement opportunity.'

2. In your group, write the voicemail message you would leave. Make up any necessary details like names, dates, and times.

3. One person from your group will 'perform' the voicemail for the class. The rest of the class must listen carefully and take notes on the key information:
• Who called?
• What was the reason for the call?

4. We will check if the listeners understood the message correctly.

Examples: calling about a work placement (`utplassering`), confirming a doctor's appointment, contacting a client for a school project, following up on a job application. Before they start, review the key parts of a good voicemail: name, reason for call, key details, and a clear callback action/number.

1. In small groups, choose one of the following vocational workplaces:

title: Online Research: Finding and Comparing Information
full_description:
This is a project that requires you to find and compare information online.

1. Choose one of the following research tasks:
• **Task A: Find the Best Smartphone Plan.** Research and compare two different mobile data plans available in Norway. Find information about price, data amount (GB), speed, and any special features. Decide which one is the best value and why.
• **Task B: Plan a Class Outing.** Visit the website for a local cinema, bowling alley, or other event venue. Find out what's on, check ticket prices, and find the opening times. Propose a specific activity for a class trip, including the total cost per person.

2. Work individually or in small groups to gather the information.

3. Prepare a short presentation to share your findings and your final recommendation with the class.

The goal is to practice practical research skills, synthesising information, and presenting a clear recommendation. You could suggest Norwegian price comparison sites (like prisjakt.no) or local venue websites (like sfkino.no) to help students start.

Sentences:

• Lucy is a nice singer.

3. In small groups, use adverbs to talk about your own skills. For example: 'I sing badly,' or 'I drive carefully.'

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a grammar-focused activity. Write the two patterns on the board: `a/an + (adjective) + (noun)` and `(verb) + (adverb)`. Complete the first example with the whole class to ensure they understand the transformation.

title: Adverb Charades
full_description:
Let's play a fun acting game to practice adverbs!

1. As a class, let's quickly brainstorm some simple actions (e.g., opening a door, eating an apple, writing an email).

2. Now, work in pairs. Student A secretly chooses an adverb from the list below.

3. Student A will mime one of the actions from the board, but they must act it out *in the manner of their secret adverb*.

4. Student B tries to guess the adverb by saying the full sentence. For example: 'You are eating an apple nervously.'

5. Swap roles and try again with a new adverb.

• Adverbs: sadly, gently, shyly, heroically, impatiently, nervously, confidently, happily, angrily, slowly, quickly, carefully, clumsily.

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a high-energy, kinesthetic activity that students usually enjoy. Model one round yourself by miming an action (e.g., brushing your teeth) in a specific way (e.g., quickly) and having the class guess the adverb to make the rules clear. Encourage exaggerated acting to make the adverb obvious.

title: "Good" vs. "Excellent": Mastering Extreme Adjectives
full_description:
1. In pairs, look at the two lists of adjectives from your teacher. Match an adjective from List 1 with a more extreme adjective from List 2 (e.g., small → tiny).

2. Discuss with your partner: What is the difference between the adjectives in the two lists?

3. Compare your answers with another pair.

4. Look at this example dialogue:
• A: This gaming setup is rather small, isn't it?
• B: Small? It's **absolutely tiny**!

5. In your pairs, write similar short dialogues using the adjective pairs you matched. Be ready to perform them for the class!

tags.teacher_instruction:
Write the words from each list in two columns on the board. For List 2, write them in a random order so students have to match them.
• List 1 (Gradable): good, clever, small, hot, happy, cold, ugly, tired, difficult, hungry, funny, interesting, large
• List 2 (Extreme/Ungradable): excellent, brilliant, tiny, boiling, thrilled, freezing, hideous, exhausted, impossible, famished, hilarious, fascinating, gigantic
Model the emphatic stress on the extreme adjective in the example dialogue (e.g., 'absolutely TINY!') and ask students to repeat it. Invite pairs to read out some of their dialogues at the end.

title: Adverb Hot Potato
full_description:
1. Stand or sit in a circle.

2. One person will throw a ball to someone else and shout out an adverb (e.g., 'Quickly!').

3. If you catch the ball, you have five seconds to use that adverb in a correct sentence (e.g., 'He ran quickly to the bus.').

4. The class will listen and decide if your sentence is grammatically correct.

5. If your sentence is not correct, or you take too long, you are out of the game for this round.

6. The last student still in the game is the winner!

tags.teacher_instruction: A soft ball or a crumpled piece of paper works perfectly for this activity. Keep the pace fast and fun to maintain energy. You can act as the first judge for sentence correctness to keep the game moving.

title: How Often Do You...? Exploring Routines
full_description:
This activity has two parts. First, we will discuss your daily habits, and then you will survey your classmates.

**Part 1: Your Habits**
1. First, let's brainstorm a list of adverbs of frequency, from 100% (always) to 0% (never).
2. In small groups, use these adverbs to talk about how often you do certain things. Your teacher will provide a list of activities. For example: 'I sometimes listen to a podcast on the bus.' or 'I almost never buy lunch at the canteen.'

**Part 2: Class Survey**
1. In pairs, look at a new list of activities from your teacher.
2. Create three questions starting with 'How often do you...?'. For example: 'How often do you go swimming?'
3. Walk around the classroom and ask your questions to at least five other students. Take notes on their answers.
4. Report your most interesting findings back to the class. For example: 'We found out that Maja goes to concerts most often.'

tags.teacher_instruction:
Part 1: Write a scale from 100% to 0% on the board and elicit adverbs of frequency (e.g., always, usually, often, sometimes, rarely, never). Provide a list of modern, relevant activities for discussion, such as:
• Post a story on Instagram/Snapchat
• Listen to a podcast
• Help with chores at home
• Speak English outside of school
• Use a ridesharing app
• Feel stressed about schoolwork
• Binge-watch a series

Part 2: Provide a different list of activities for the survey part, such as: clean your shoes, eat spicy food, go swimming, fly, write an email, argue, go to a concert, laugh, get a haircut, sing.

The original activity included a trivia section about science facts which has been removed to focus on personal communication.

title: Apostrophe 's' Dictation Challenge
full_description:
1. Your teacher will read a short text to you twice. Write down exactly what you hear.

2. After the dictation, compare your text with a partner to check for any differences.

3. Now, look through your text and circle every time you see an apostrophe 's' (for example: `Maja's`).

4. In your pair, decide what each 's' means. Is it:
• a) a short form of 'is' (e.g., He's happy.)
• b) a short form of 'has' (e.g., She's got a new phone.)
• c) a short form of 'us' (e.g., Let's go.)
• d) a possessive 's' showing ownership (e.g., Liam's friend.)

tags.teacher_instruction:
Read the following text at a natural pace. Read it a second time for students to check their work. After they analyze the apostrophes, go through the answers as a class.

Text: 'Hey, what's up? Listen, there's a get-together at Maja's place. She's invited some friends over. Liam's going, and his classmate, what's her name, Sara. She's a gamer and she's got a great sense of humor. It's been ages since I went to Maja's. It's going to be fun. She's making tacos and she's got some sodas, but let's bring some snacks too. There's a shop that's just opened near Liam's. It's called ‘Søtt og Salt’. Let's meet there at seven. OK, see you later.'

title: Guess Who: Possessive 's' Game
full_description:
1. In pairs, discuss what you know about each other's preferences and skills. For example: 'Anna's favorite subject is practical work.' or 'Marius's playlist is full of hip-hop.'

2. On your own, write a list of five 'guesses' about other students in the class. Use the possessive 's'. For example: 'I think Ingrid's favorite video game is Minecraft.' or 'Perhaps Sondre's dream is to be a mechanic.'

3. Take turns reading out one of your guesses to the class. The student you named can then say if you are right or wrong!

title: Celebrity Profile: Contractions vs. Possessives
full_description:
1. In small groups, choose a famous person that you all know (e.g., a musician, actor, or athlete).

2. Look at the list of features your teacher provides (e.g., *blue eyes, famous songs, new movie, signature hairstyle*).

3. Your task is to write pairs of sentences about your chosen celebrity. One sentence must use a possessive 's' (showing ownership), and the other must use a contraction of 'is' or 'has'.

For example, if you choose Erling Haaland:
• Erling Haaland's hairstyle is famous. (possessive)
• Erling Haaland's got a famous hairstyle. (contraction of 'has')

4. Share your best sentence pair with the class.

tags.teacher_instruction: You can suggest a few well-known celebrities relevant to the students if they have trouble choosing. Write a list of features on the board to guide them, for example: blue eyes, red hair, new album, big muscles, nice voice, famous movie.

title: Article Chains and Gap-Fill
full_description:
**Part 1: Article Chains**
1. Let's start a sentence chain as a class. I'll start with 'There's a word on a page.'
2. The next person continues, turning 'a page' into 'the page'. For example: 'The page is in a book.'
3. The next person continues: 'The book is on a table.' We will continue the chain for as long as we can!
4. In small groups, create your own chains starting with one of these:
• There's a file on a computer...
• There's a problem with an engine...

**Part 2: Sentence Gap-Fill**
1. In pairs, write one complete sentence that contains both 'a/an' and 'the'. For example: 'A mechanic fixed the car.'
2. On a separate piece of paper, rewrite your sentence but leave blank spaces for every word EXCEPT 'a/an' and 'the'. For example: 'A ______ ______ the ______.'
3. Swap your gapped sentence with another pair. Fill in the gaps in the sentence you receive in any creative way you can!

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, write up the first sentence sequence on the board to demonstrate the pattern: There's a word on a page. The page is in a book. The book is on a table...

title: Explaining Situations with 'Used To'
full_description:
In pairs, listen to the situations your teacher reads out. Your task is to agree on a possible explanation for each situation and write it down using 'be used to' or 'get used to'.

For example, if the teacher says: 'I'm so tired this week.'
Your explanation could be: 'I'm not used to starting work so early.' or 'I can't get used to the new schedule.'

Listen to the prompts and write your explanations. Afterwards, compare your ideas with another pair. Which explanation do you think is best?

tags.teacher_instruction:
Read the following prompts one by one, giving pairs time to write an explanation for each. 
Prompts:
• Don't touch my tools!
• Slow down!
• I'm afraid I've dented your car.
• I find my new boss difficult to work with.
• They don't like living in Oslo.
• It was so embarrassing.
• My dog doesn't like the city.
• I can't drink this coffee.
• This country is too cold for me.

title: Email Home: Life as an Apprentice Abroad
full_description:
Imagine you are a young Norwegian student who has moved to another country (like the UK or USA) for an apprenticeship or to study. 

In pairs, write an email to your parents telling them about life in the new city. You must use different forms of 'be used to' and 'get used to'.

For example: 'I've got used to drinking coffee without milk, but I can't get used to the food. I'm getting used to driving on the other side of the road. I'll never get used to the weather!'

Try to write about these aspects of life:
• food
• fashion
• shopping
• traffic
• language
• work culture
• the weather

tags.teacher_instruction: This is a creative writing task focusing on the target grammar. Encourage students to be imaginative about the challenges and surprises of living abroad. You can write the list of 'aspects of life' on the board for inspiration.

title: This or That? Preference Survey
full_description:
**Part 1: Partner Discussion**
In pairs, discuss these questions about your preferences. Explain your choices!
• Which do you prefer, TikTok or Instagram?
• Do you prefer to learn by watching videos or by reading?
• Do you prefer cats or dogs? Why?
• Would you rather be famous but have no privacy, or be unknown but have total freedom? Why?

**Part 2: Class Survey**
1. In your pair, create two new 'preference' questions to ask the class.
2. Choose one question each and survey everyone in the class.
3. Be prepared to report your results back to the group. For example: 'Most people in our class would rather be unknown than famous.'

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 1, read the questions out one at a time and allow a few minutes for discussion. Encourage students to use comparative language in their answers (e.g., 'TikTok is more entertaining, but Instagram is better for photos.'). The survey in Part 2 gets students moving and interacting with everyone.

title: Comparing Countries: Norway vs. ...
full_description:
**Part 1: Group Discussion**
In groups of three or four, compare Norway to another country you know well (like the USA, UK, Spain, or a neighboring country). Discuss the questions below:
• Is the other country hotter or colder than Norway? Wetter or drier?
• Is it cheaper or more expensive to live there?
• What are some other big differences?
• What things are better in Norway? What things are better in the other country?

**Part 2: Guess the Country Game (Optional)**
1. In pairs, your teacher will give you a secret country.
2. Write a list of 5 sentences comparing your secret country to Norway. Use the list of adjectives for ideas (e.g., *big, green, mountainous, expensive, safe*).
3. Read your comparisons aloud to the class. The other groups must try to guess your secret country!

tags.teacher_instruction: For Part 2, prepare a few country names on slips of paper to give to pairs. Write a list of useful comparative adjectives on the board: big, small, developed, green, corrupt, hot, cold, mountainous, expensive, tolerant, safe, rich.

title: Debate Game: Yes, but...
full_description:
1. Divide into two teams.

2. In your team, work together to write ten simple opinion sentences using an adjective. For example: 'Electric cars are expensive.' or 'TikTok is entertaining.'

3. Teams will take turns reading out one of their sentences.

4. A player from the other team must immediately respond with a counter-argument using a comparative. The response must start with 'Yes, but...'.

For example:
• Team A: 'Electric cars are expensive.'
• Team B: 'Yes, but gasoline cars are worse for the environment.'

5. The goal is to respond quickly and correctly!

title: Comparative Brainstorm Race
full_description:
